{{Infobox song | name = Famous | cover = Famouscover1.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Kanye West]] | album = [[The Life of Pablo]] | released = {{Start date|2016|04|1}} | format = {{hlist|[[Music download|Digital download]]|[[Streaming media|streaming]]}} | recorded = 2015 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | length = {{Duration|m=3|s=14}} | label = {{hlist|[[GOOD Music|GOOD]]|[[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]]}} | writer = {{collapsible list|title=Various|hlist=true|[[Kanye West]]|[[Cyhi the Prynce|Cydel Young]]|[[Havoc (musician)|Kejuan Muchita]]|Noah Goldstein|[[Andrew Dawson (record producer)|Andrew Dawson]]|[[Mike Dean (record producer)|Mike Dean]]|[[Chance the Rapper|Chancelor Bennett]]|[[Swizz Beatz|Kasseem Dean]]|[[Charlie Heat|Ernest Brown]]|[[Hudson Mohawke|Ross Birchard]]|[[Plain Pat|Pat Reynolds]]|[[Jimmy Webb]]|[[Winston Riley]]|[[Luis Bacalov|Luis Enriquez Bacalov]]|[[Il Rovescio della Medaglia|Enzo Vita]]|[[Sergio Bardotti]]|[[Giampiero Scalamogna]]}} | producer = {{collapsible list|title=Various|hlist=true|West|[[Havoc (musician)|Havoc]]|Goldstein {{small|(co.)}}|[[Charlie Heat]] {{small|(co.)}}|Andrew Dawson {{small|(co.)}}|[[Hudson Mohawke]] {{small|(addl.)}}|Mike Dean {{small|(addl.)}}|[[Plain Pat]] {{small|(addl.)}}}} | prev_title = [[One Man Can Change the World]] | prev_year = 2015 | next_title = [[Pop Style]] | next_year = 2016 | misc = {{External music video|{{Youtube|p7FCgw_GlWc|"Famous"}}}} }} "'''Famous'''" is a song by American rapper [[Kanye West]]. It serves as the lead single from his seventh studio album ''[[The Life of Pablo]]'' (2016). The song features uncredited vocals from Barbadian singer [[Rihanna]] and ad-libs from American hip hop artist [[Swizz Beatz]], and enlists [[music sample|samples]] of Jamaican singer [[Sister Nancy]], American singer [[Nina Simone]] and Italian band Il Rovescio Della Medaglia.{{cite web|url=http://www.whosampled.com/Kanye-West/Famous/| title=Kanye West: Famous |publisher= WhoSampled |language=En |accessdate= 3 April 2016}} The single was serviced to US [[Urban contemporary|urban]] and [[Rhythmic contemporary|rhythmic]] radio stations on April 1, 2016.{{cite web|url= http://www.idolator.com/7627869/kanye-west-rihanna-famous-life-of-pablo-tlop-single |title=Kanye West & Rihanna's "Famous" Will Be the First Single Off 'The Life of Pablo'|publisher= Idolater |accessdate= March 25, 2016 |date= March 27, 2016}}{{cite web|url= http://hiphop-n-more.com/2016/03/kanye-releases-famous-ft-rihanna-as-1st-single-from-the-life-of-pablo/ |title= Kanye Releases 'Famous' Ft. Rihanna As 1st Single From 'The Life of Pablo' |publisher= HipHop-N-More |accessdate= March 25, 2016 |date= March 27, 2016}} Upon its release, "Famous" was met with both critical acclaim and scrutiny for a controversial lyrical reference to American singer [[Taylor Swift]], partially in relation to West's [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards controversy|interruption]] of her [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards|2009 VMA]] acceptance speech.{{cite web|last=Kreps |first=Daniel |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/kanye-west-defends-controversial-taylor-swift-famous-lyric-20160212 |title=Kanye West Defends Controversial Taylor Swift 'Famous' Lyric |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2016-02-12 |accessdate=2016-04-16}}{{cite web|author=Evan Minsker |url=http://pitchfork.com/news/63491-kanye-on-taylor-swift-controversy-its-actually-something-taylor-came-up-with/ |title=Kanye on Taylor Swift Controversy: "It's Actually Something Taylor Came Up With" |publisher=Pitchfork |date=2016-02-11 |accessdate=2016-04-16}}{{cite web|last=Renner |first=Eric |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/04/11/kanye-west-taylor-swift-controversy |title=Kanye West addresses Taylor Swift controversy |website=EW.com |date=2016-04-11 |accessdate=2016-04-16}}{{cite web|author=Chris Payne |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/6874893/kanye-west-taylor-swift-lyric-defend-twitter |title=Kanye West Defends Controversial Taylor Swift Lyric in Twitter Spree |publisher=Billboard |date= |accessdate=2016-04-16}}{{cite web|author=Mark Molloy |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/news/taylor-swift-does-not-approve-of-misogynistic-kanye-west-lyrics/ |title=Kanye West defends controversial lyrics about Taylor Swift in Twitter rant |website=Telegraph.co.uk |date=2016-02-12 |accessdate=2016-04-16}} After West claimed to have obtained Swift's approval over the criticized lyric, Swift denied the claim, criticizing West and denouncing the lyric as "misogynistic" in a statement. Several months later, West's wife [[Kim Kardashian]] released a video capturing a conversation between Swift and West in which Swift appears to approve the lyric.{{cite web|last1=Yoo|first1=Noah|title=Kim Kardashian Leaks Video Confirming Taylor Swift Signed Off on Kanye's Infamous "Famous" Line|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/66880-kim-kardashian-reveals-taylor-swift-signed-off-on-kanyes-infamous-famous-line/|website=[[Pitchfork Media]]|accessdate=19 July 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Abad-Santos|first1=Alex|title=Kim Kardashian's Taylor Swift-Kanye West Snapchat story, explained|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/7/18/12210858/kim-kardashian-taylor-swift-snapchat-kanye-west|website=[[Vox (magazine)|Vox]]|accessdate=19 July 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Jamieson Cox and Matthew Davis|title=Kim Kardashian used Snapchat to prove Taylor Swift was lying about Kanye West's Famous|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/17/12210852/kim-kardashian-snapchat-taylor-swift-kanye-west-famous|website=[[The Verge]]|accessdate=19 July 2016}} In June 2016, West released a music video for "Famous" depicting wax figures of West, Swift, Kardashian, [[George W. Bush]], [[Donald Trump]], [[Anna Wintour]], [[Rihanna]], [[Chris Brown]], [[Ray J]], [[Amber Rose]], [[Caitlyn Jenner]], and [[Bill Cosby]] all sleeping nude in a shared bed. It was released to a polarized response. The wax figures used in the video were later exhibited as a sculpture. The song was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Rap/Sung Performance|Best Rap/Sung Performance]] and [[Grammy Award for Best Rap Song|Best Rap Song]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards]]. ==Composition== "Famous" features a segue from "braggadocious, bell-ringing hip-hop" into samples of [[Sister Nancy]]'s [[dancehall]] song "[[Bam Bam (song)|Bam Bam]]" chopped up over the chord progression featured in [[Nina Simone]]'s "Do What You Gotta Do".{{Sfn|Raymer|2016}} After the initial release of ''The Life of Pablo'', "Famous" was among the several tracks to receive alterations in West's March 2016 update of the album; changes included a different mix and slightly altered lyrics.{{cite web|last1=Helman|first1=Peter|title=Kanye West's Updated The Life Of Pablo Is Now On Apple Music And Spotify|url=http://www.stereogum.com/1868554/kanye-wests-updated-the-life-of-pablo-will-reportedly-be-on-apple-music-and-spotify-this-friday/news/|website=[[Stereogum]]|accessdate=June 23, 2016}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== "Famous" was well received by music critics. For the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', [[Greg Kot]] called the song "an example of just how brilliant and infuriating West can be at the same time," noting its controversial Taylor Swift-referencing lyric while going on to praise the production and [[Rihanna]]'s guest vocals.{{cite news|ref=harv|last=Kot|first=Greg|authorlink=Greg Kot|year=2016|issue=February 16|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/kot/ct-kanye-west-pablo-review-ent-0217-20160215-column.html|title=Kanye West's bewildering, frustrating 'Pablo'|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=April 6, 2016}} Jayson Greene of [[Pitchfork (website)|''Pitchfork'']] wrote that the controversial lyric "feels like a piece of bathroom graffiti made to purposefully reignite the most racially-charged rivalry in 21st-century pop."{{sfn|Greene|2016}} ''[[The Guardian]]'''s [[Alexis Petridis]] described the song's position on ''The Life of Pablo'' as being: 'a flatly fantastic piece of music that may be the best thing on the album'.{{cite web|last1=Petridis|first1=Alexis|title=Kanye West: The Life of Pablo review – 'You can see why his immodesty rubs people up the wrong way'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/14/kanye-west-the-life-of-pablo-review-you-can-see-why-his-immodesty-rubs-people-up-the-wrong-way|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' staff named "Famous" one of the best songs of the year 2016 and wrote of it that: "Kanye West is a genius musician and a world-class provocateur, and "Famous" is yet another piece of proof those two qualities are inextricably intertwined. He weaves ''The Life of Pablo''{{'}}s hardest-knocking beat, chords cribbed from [[Nina Simone]], and [[Sister Nancy]]'s reggae classic "Bam Bam" into a vibrant tapestry, and he uses all of that beauty to crack open his long-simmering spat with the biggest pop star on the planet. The court of public opinion won't ever reach a verdict on Taylor [Swift] v. Kanye — did she consent to being mentioned? Did she double-cross Kanye? At least we can all agree that "Famous" captures West in all of his complicated, vital glory."{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Jamieson|title=The Top 10 Best Songs|url=http://time.com/4575319/top-10-best-songs-2016/|website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=December 13, 2016}} ===Accolades=== The track was positioned at number 10 on ''Time'''s list of 2016's best songs. ''[[HotNewHipHop]]'' placed it at number 43 on their list of West's 50 best songs.{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Danny|title=Top 50 Best Kanye West Songs|url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/top-50-best-kanye-west-songs-news.39731.html|website=[[HotNewHipHop]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} The song received [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nominations for [[Grammy Award for Best Rap/Sung Performance|Best Rap/Sung Performance]] and [[Grammy Award for Best Rap Song|Best Rap Song]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards]] in 2017, but ended up losing both to "[[Hotline Bling]]" by Canadian rapper and singer [[Drake (musician)|Drake]].{{cite web|title=Grammy Awards 2017: See the Full Winners List|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/grammys/7686168/grammy-awards-2017-winners-list|website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018|date=February 12, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180202113320/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/grammys/7686168/grammy-awards-2017-winners-list|archive-date=February 2, 2018}} ==Controversy== {{multiple image | align = right | footer = In July 2016, West's wife [[Kim Kardashian]] (left) released a video recording of [[Taylor Swift]] (right) granting her approval of the controversial lyrics after Swift denied that the recording existed. | image1 = Kim_Kardashian_West,_Parramatta_Westfield_Sydney_Australia_-_15035243919_(cropped).jpg | width1 = 149 | image2 = TaylorSwiftApr09.jpg | width2 = 158 }} The song includes a controversial lyric in reference to West's [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards controversy|interruption]] of singer [[Taylor Swift]]'s [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards|2009 VMA]] acceptance speech and its aftermath:
"For all my [[South Side, Chicago|South Side]] niggas that know me best
I feel like me and [[Taylor Swift|Taylor]] might still have sex
Why? I made that bitch famous
(Goddamn!)
I made that bitch famous."
Upon the song's release, the lyric was heavily publicized and criticized by media outlets, though West defended the line, saying, "I called Taylor and had a {{sic}} hour long convo with her about the line and she thought it was funny and gave her blessings." In response, Swift's spokesperson adamantly denied that West asked for her approval for the controversial lyric,http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6874870/taylor-swift-cautioned-kanye-west-famous-misogynistic with an official statement claiming that Swift had only been asked to release West's song on her Twitter page, and had instead "cautioned him against releasing a song with such a strong [[misogynistic]] message." In Swift's 2016 [[Grammy Awards]] victory speech for Best Album, she seemingly made a veiled reference to West's lyric, referring to "those people along the way who are going to try to undercut your success or take credit for your accomplishments or your ''fame.''"{{cite web|last1=Lee|first1=Esther|title=Taylor Swift Snipes Back at Kanye West in Grammys 2016 Album of the Year Speech: People Will Try to 'Take Credit for Your Fame'|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/taylor-swift-snipes-at-kanye-west-in-grammys-2016-album-of-the-year-speech-w164478|website=[[Us Weekly]]|accessdate=19 July 2016}} In a June 2016 interview with ''[[GQ]]'', West's wife [[Kim Kardashian West]] claimed the couple possessed a video recording of West's phone call with Swift, in which Swift could be heard amiably discussing and approving the lyrics. She clarified that Swift's camp had threatened legal action should the video be released, and argued that "I swear, my husband gets so much shit for things [when] he really was doing proper protocol and even called to get it approved."{{cite web|last1=Strauss|first1=Matthew|title=Kim Kardashian Says Taylor Swift "Totally Approved" Kanye's "Famous" (And They Have It on Video)|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/66148-kim-kardashian-says-taylor-swift-totally-approved-kanyes-famous-and-they-have-it-on-video/|website=[[Pitchfork Media]]|accessdate=19 July 2016}} In July 2016, Kardashian posted a recording of the phone conversation online, in which Swift can allegedly be heard approving West's lyric, describing it as a "compliment" and a show of friendship.http://pitchfork.com/news/66880-kim-kardashian-reveals-taylor-swift-signed-off-on-kanyes-infamous-famous-line/https://www.gq.com/story/kim-kardashian-west-gq-cover-story Due to the release of this video, Swift has been accused of lying about approving the lyric. In the call, Swift appears to say:
Yeah, go with whatever line makes you feel better, it's obviously very [[tongue-in-cheek]] either way. And I really appreciate you telling me about it, that's really nice [...] I don't think anyone would listen to that and be like 'that's a real [[Diss track|diss]], she must be crying.' You've gotta tell the story the way that it happened to you and the way that you experienced it. You honestly didn't know who I was before that. It doesn't matter that I sold 7 million of that album before you did that which is what happened, you didn't know who I was before that. It's fine. [...] If people ask me about it, I think it would be great for me to be like, ‘Look, he called me and told me about the line.'
West can be heard telling Swift, "I just had a responsibility to you as a friend, you know, and thanks for being so cool about it." Following the video's release, Swift released a statement stating "being falsely painted as a liar when I was never given the full story or played any part of the song is character assassination," claiming West did not tell her she would be referred to as "that bitch." On the same day as the video's release, Kardashian tweeted about National Snake Day, saying "They have holidays for everybody, I mean everything these days! 🐍". This tweet was interpreted as being aimed at Swift, and the [[hashtag]] #TaylorSwiftIsASnake became trending. In September 2016, Swift started using a filter created by [[Instagram]] CEO [[Kevin Systrom]] to automatically delete comments using the snake emoji on her profile. By August 2017, Swift was using snakes in promotional material for her 2017 album ''[[Reputation (Taylor Swift album)|Reputation]]''. They were worked into merchandise, the music video for its lead single "[[Look What You Made Me Do]]", and her 2018 [[Taylor Swift's Reputation Stadium Tour|Reputation Stadium Tour]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/08/22/entertainment/taylor-swift-snakes/index.html|title=Taylor Swift and snakes: The backstory|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=22 August 2017|accessdate=1 March 2018|author=Lisa Respers France}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7934297/taylor-swift-the-snake-history-kim-kanye-instagram|title=The History of Taylor Swift & the Snake|publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''|date=21 August 2017|accessdate=1 March 2018|author=Alexandra Holterman}} In October 2016, the demo version leaked, revealing different lyrics on Swift and [[Amber Rose]].{{cite web | url=http://people.com/music/kanye-west-famous-demo-taylor-swift-sex/ | title=Kanye West’s ‘Famous’ Demo Leaked, Reveals Different Lyrics on Taylor Swift and Amber Rose | work=People | date=October 6, 2016 | accessdate=October 6, 2016}} ==Music video== [[File:Kanye West Famous Music Video.jpg|thumb|right|The controversial music video featured nude wax sculptures of several celebrities. From left to right:[https://www.elle.com/culture/celebrities/g28419/guide-to-celebrities-in-kanye-famous-video/ A Who's Who Guide to Kanye's 'Famous' Video]
1. [[George W. Bush]] 2. [[Anna Wintour]] 3. [[Donald Trump]] 4. [[Rihanna]] 5. [[Chris Brown]] 6.[[Taylor Swift]] 7. [[Kanye West]] 8. [[Kim Kardashian]] 9. [[Ray J]] 10. [[Amber Rose]] 11. [[Caitlyn Jenner]] 12. [[Bill Cosby]]]] The song's music video premiered at a [[Tidal (service)|Tidal]] exclusive event at [[The Forum (Inglewood, California)|The Forum]] in [[Inglewood, California]] on June 24, 2016. The video begins with a camera passing slowly over the nude, lookalike sleeping bodies of famous personalities. All of the celebrities are synthetic bodies. At the end of the video, the camera pans out to show all of the sleeping bodies at the same time as West wakes up from his slumber.{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7416556/kanye-west-naked-taylor-swift-donald-trump-famous-video-premiere | title=Kanye West Nuzzles Naked Taylor Swift, Donald Trump & Bill Cosby in 'Famous' Video | work=Billboard | date=June 25, 2016 | accessdate=June 25, 2016}} [[Vincent Desiderio]]'s painting ''Sleep'' is the visual inspiration for the video.Coscarelli, Joe. "The Artist Providing the Canvas for Kanye West's ‘Famous’ Video." ''The New York Times''. June 29, 2016 Two days prior to the video's release, West showed the video to Dirk Standen of ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' over [[Skype]] while the video was still in its final editing stages. The video was filmed over a period of three months and went through four different versions prior to the finalized version. West did not reveal which of the celebrities' bodies in the video were real and which ones were [[prosthetic]]; however he stated that the video was "not in support or [against] any of [the people in the video]" and was merely "a comment on fame". He also stated that he received his wife Kardashian's permission.http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2016/06/kanye-famous-video-interview Days after its release, ''[[E! Online]]'' editor Corinne Heller commented, "Swift is the main reason the 'Famous' video was so anticipated." However, it received "almost no reactions" from the celebrities portrayed.{{cite web | url=http://www.eonline.com/news/775796/kanye-west-gets-almost-no-reactions-from-stars-depicted-naked-in-famous-video | title=Kanye West Gets Almost No Reactions From Stars Depicted Naked in "Famous" Video | work=E! Online | date=June 26, 2016 | accessdate=June 28, 2016}} Audience response to the video was polarized.{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Will|title=Kanye West 'Famous' premiere: 4 things you missed|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/06/25/kanye-west-famous-visual-premiere|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=19 July 2016}} The video of the song was uploaded to [[YouTube]] on July 1, 2016. West's song "[[Father Stretch My Hands|Father Stretch My Hands Pt. 1]]" is also featured in the video.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p7FCgw_GlWc|title=Kanye West - Famous|publisher=[[VEVO]]|accessdate=July 3, 2016}} The video earned nominations for [[MTV Video Music Award for Best Male Video|Best Male Video]] and [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]] at the [[2016 MTV Video Music Awards]]. As well as [[MTV Video Music Award Japan for Best Hip-Hop Video|Best Hip-Hop Video]] at the [[2016 MTV Video Music Awards Japan]].{{cite web|title=VMAJ 2016: Best Hip-Hop Video|url=http://www.mtvjapan.com/vmaj2016/nominees/best-hiphop-video/|website=MTV Japan|accessdate=16 December 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170917064501/http://www.mtvjapan.com/vmaj2016/nominees/best-hiphop-video/|archivedate=17 September 2017}} German director [[Werner Herzog]] expressed admiration for the video, describing it as "very good stuff" and admitting he had "never seen anything like this."{{cite web|last1=Walsh|first1=April Clare|title=Werner Herzog analysing Kanye West’s ‘Famous’ video is everything you want it to be and more|url=http://www.factmag.com/2016/08/12/watch-werner-herzog-analyse-kanye-west-famous-video/|website=[[Fact (UK magazine)|Fact]]|accessdate=12 August 2016}} The sculptures depicted in the music video are on a gallery tour, and some estimates for its sale are as high as $4 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/01/arts/design/gallery-hopes-to-sell-kanye-wests-famous-sculpture-for-4-million.html|title=Gallery Hopes to Sell Kanye West’s ‘Famous’ Sculpture for $4 Million|last=Popescu|first=Adam|date=2016-08-31|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-09-01}} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2016) ! scope="col"| Peak

Bush]] [[Category:Kanye West songs]] [[Category:Music video controversies]] [[Category:Obscenity controversies in music]] [[Category:Rihanna songs]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Charlie Heat]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Hudson Mohawke]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Kanye West]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Mike Dean (record producer)]] [[Category:Songs about celebrities]] [[Category:Songs written by Chance the Rapper]] [[Category:Songs written by Cyhi the Prynce]] [[Category:Songs written by Havoc (musician)]] [[Category:Songs written by Jimmy Webb]] [[Category:Songs written by Kanye West]] [[Category:Songs written by Mike Dean (record producer)]] [[Category:Songs written by Plain Pat]] [[Category:Songs written by Swizz Beatz]] [[Category:Swizz Beatz songs]]

{{about|the gambling game played with small objects|the card game|Sevens (card game)|the aircraft|Nanchang Q-5}} [[File:Fantan gambling, Canton, Kwangtung province, China LCCN2001705605.tif|thumb|Photo of a fan-tan game in Canton, China, by [[Lai Afong]]]]
'''Fan-Tan''', or '''fantan''' ({{zh|t=番攤 |s=番摊 |p=fāntān}}, literally "repeated divisions") is a form of a [[gambling]] game long played in China. It has similarities to [[roulette]].
==History== [[File:Fan-Tan in New York City 1887.jpg|thumb|right|A page from ''[[Frank Leslie's Weekly|Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper]]'' depicting a fan-tan parlor in New York, a raid by the police, and cards and coins used in fan-tan, in December 1887.]]
The game may have arisen during third and fourth centuries, during the period of the [[Northern and Southern dynasties]].<ref>{{cite book | author1 = Guo Shuanglin | author2 = Xiao Meihua | title = Zhongguo dubu shi | trans-title = History of gaming in China | location = Taibei | publisher = Wenjin chubanshe | year = 1996 | page = 225}}</ref> It then spread through southern China during the [[Qing dynasty]].<ref name=Paules>{{cite journal | url = http://www.reseau-asie.com/cgi-bin/prog/gateway.cgi?langue=fr&password=&email=&dir=myfile_colloque&type=jhg54gfd98gfd4fgd4gfdg&id=421&telecharge_now=1&file=a37paules_xavier.pdf | dead-url = yes | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110715174717/http://www.reseau-asie.com/cgi-bin/prog/gateway.cgi?langue=fr&password=&email=&dir=myfile_colloque&type=jhg54gfd98gfd4fgd4gfdg&id=421&telecharge_now=1&file=a37paules_xavier.pdf | archive-date = 15 July 2011 | title = « Le fantan, une étude préliminaire » | trans-title = The fantan, a preliminary study | format = PDF | language = French | first = Xavier | last = Paulès | work = Atelier 37 : Le Jeu en Asie / Workshop 37 : Gambling in Asia, 3ème Congrès du Réseau Asie - IMASIE / 3rd Congress of Réseau Asie - IMASIE | date = 26–28 September 2007 | location = Paris, France }}</ref> The name fantan dates back only to the mid-nineteenth century. Before that time, ''fantan'' was known as ''yanqian'' 掩錢 (literally meaning “covering coins”, ''tanxi'' 攤 戲, ''tanqian'' 攤錢, ''yiqian'' 意錢.<ref> Xavier Paulès, « Gambling in China reconsidered: ''fantan'' in South China during the early twentieth century », ''International Journal of Asian Studies'', vol. 7, n° 2 (July 2010), p. 179-200. </ref> It was prominent during the [[Republic of China (1912–49)|Republican period]], in Canton and the Pearl River Delta region.<ref name=Paules />.
After 1850, ''fantan'' spread overseas as a side effect of the massive Cantonese emigration. As a rule, in places were a significant number of Cantonese migrants could be found, ''fantan'' was also present<ref> Xavier Paulès, “An illustration of China’s “paradoxical soft power”: the dissemination of the gambling game ''fantan'' 番攤 by the Cantonese diaspora, 1850-1950”, ''Translocal Chinese: East Asian perspectives,'' vol. 11, no. 2 (Fall 2017), p. 187-207. </ref>. Fan-tan was very popular among Chinese migrants in America, as most of them were of Cantonese origin.<ref name=Paules /><ref name=Culin>{{citation | url = http://healthy.uwaterloo.ca/museum/Archives/Culin/Gambling1891/ | title = The Gambling Games Of The Chinese In America | first = Stewart | last = Culin | work = Series in Philology Literature and Archaeology | volume = I | issue = 4 | location = Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA | publisher = University of Pennsylvania Press | date = 1891 | access-date = August 30, 2017}}</ref> [[Jacob Riis]], in his famous book about the underbelly of New York, ''[[How the Other Half Lives]]'' (1890), wrote of entering a [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Chinatown]] fan-tan parlor: "At the first foot-fall of leather soles on the steps the hum of talk ceases, and the group of celestials, crouching over their game of fan tan, stop playing and watch the comer with ugly looks. Fan tan is their ruling passion." The large [[Chinatown, San Francisco|Chinatown in San Francisco]] was also home to dozens of fan-tan houses in the 19th century. The city's former police commissioner Jesse B. Cook wrote that in 1889 Chinatown had 50 fan-tan games, and that "in the 50 fan tan gambling houses the tables numbered from one to 24, according to the size of the room."
Fan-tan is no longer as popular as it once was, having been replaced by modern [[casino]] games, and other traditional Chinese games such as [[Mah Jong]] and [[Pai Gow]]. Fan-tan is still played at some [[Gambling in Macau|Macau casinos]].<ref name=Macau>{{cite web | url = https://wizardofmacau.com/games/fantan.html | title = Fan Tan in Macau | | first = James | last = K. | date = 1 April 2009 | work = The Wizard of Macau | access-date = 30 August 2017}}</ref>
==The game== A square is marked in the center of an ordinary table, or a square piece of metal is laid on it, the sides being marked 1, 2, 3 and 4. The banker puts on the table a double handful of small buttons, beads, coins, dried beans, or similar articles, which he covers with a metal bowl, or "tan koi".
The players then bet on the numbers, setting their stakes on the side of the square which bears the number selected. Players can also bet on the corners, for example between No. 2 and No. 3. When all bets are placed, the bowl is removed and the "tan kun", or [[croupier]], uses a small [[bamboo]] stick to remove the buttons from the heap, four at a time, until the final batch is reached. If it contains four buttons, the backer of No. 4 wins; if three, the backer of No. 3 wins; if two, the backer of No. 2 wins and if one the backer of No. 1 wins.
All winning wagers are paid true odds less a house commission,<ref name=Culin /> which ranges from 5% to 25% depending on the establishment.<ref name=Macau /><ref>{{citation | url = https://transcription.si.edu/transcribe/9572/SIA-SIA2016-011518 | first = Edmund | last = Heller | title = Handwritten China journal | volume = 5 | year = 1917 | quote = ...less 10% for the house.}}</ref><ref>The 1911 ''Encyclopaedia Britannica'' says "Twenty-five per cent of the stake is deducted by the banker..."</ref> For example, assume a bettor has $100 wagered on a 3 to 1 wager; if the bet wins, the bettor is paid $285 ($300 less 5%).
==See also== *[[Barbu (card game)]] *[[Three-card monte]]
==References== *{{1911|title=FANTAN|page=171}} {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat}} *[http://www.chinesecol.com/treasure5.html Picture of a Fan-Tan set]
[[Category:Chinese ancient games]] [[Category:Gambling games]]

revision.comment: /* top */updating {{[[Template:Infobox television episode|Infobox television episode]]}} parameters ([[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/NihlusBOT 3|Task 3]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox television episode | title = Ginger Cow | series = South Park | season = 17 | episode = 6 | image = | caption = | director = [[Trey Parker]] | writer = Trey Parker | music = "[[Ain't Talkin' 'Bout Love]]"
by [[Van Halen]]
"[[Hot for Teacher]]"
by Van Halen | airdate = {{Start date|2013|11|6}} | production = 1706 | season_article = South Park (season 17) | episode_list = List of South Park episodes | prev = [[Taming Strange]] | next = [[Black Friday (South Park)|Black Friday]] }} "'''Ginger Cow'''" is the sixth episode in the [[South Park (season 17)|seventeenth season]] of the American animated television series ''[[South Park]]''. The 243rd episode of the series overall, it first aired on [[Comedy Central]] in the United States on November 6, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsroomamerica.com/story/393570.html |title=Episode 1706 "Ginger Cow" Press Release|publisher=NewsRoomAmerica.com |date=November 4, 2013}} In the episode, [[Eric Cartman|Cartman]] modifies a cow to make it look like a [[Red hair|ginger]] as a joke. However, various religious groups see this as a prophecy being fulfilled and peace is brought to the Middle East. ==Plot== At South Park Elementary, [[Eric Cartman|Cartman]] announces that he wishes to apologize to [[Kyle Broflovski|Kyle]], saying that Kyle was correct the previous day when he told Cartman that humans are not the only animals that can have [[light skin]] and [[freckle]]s. Telling them that he has discovered a ginger cow, Cartman takes his classmates to a nearby farm, where he shows them a cow that has been given a red wig and painted white with giant red "freckles". Though Kyle sees through this obvious prank, Cartman insists to his credulous classmates that it is real. News of the cow spreads across the globe and is widely interpreted as the fulfillment of a Biblical prophecy regarding a [[red heifer]] that signals "the end", or the [[end times]]. Kyle is then called to Mr. Mackey's office, where he is introduced to three Israeli [[rabbis]], who explain the prophecy to him. Kyle tries to convince them that the red heifer is a forgery on Cartman's part, but the farm where the cow is located becomes a pilgrimage site where large numbers of [[Jews]], [[Muslim]]s, and [[Christian]]s congregate, each claiming the cow for their respective religions. However, when the three religious sects meet to plan [[Armageddon]], they realize that they are negotiating in a civil manner and that the prophecy may have meant that the cow would signal the end of war, and not the end of the world. The congregants then agree to [[animal sacrifice|sacrifice]] the cow in order to fulfill the prophecy. Peace is achieved in the Middle East among the three [[Abrahamic religions]], who morph the [[Christian cross|cross]], [[Star of David]], and [[Hilal (crescent moon)|Islamic crescent moon]] into a new unifying symbol – the logo of the band [[Van Halen]], which appears on a stage to commence a 10-year concert in Israel. Cartman then appears at Kyle's house and admits that the cow was a forgery and states that he intends to admit this publicly. Realizing that this revelation may ruin the interfaith peace that the forgery achieved, Kyle asks him not to. Cartman agrees to withhold this information, on condition that Kyle do everything that Cartman says, which includes indignities such as insulting his own mother [[Gerald and Sheila Broflovski|Sheila]] to her face, performing menial tasks and humiliating himself in public by allowing Cartman to fart in his face and claiming that he enjoys it. Kyle, who is conflicted over the morality of the deception, experiences a vision of a spirit that praises his sacrifice and compels him to shave his head. However, [[Stan Marsh|Stan]] becomes critical of Kyle, telling him that while publicly claiming to like Cartman's farts is his prerogative, the [[self-righteous]] manner that he has adopted when doing so is not. Kyle is unmoved, and Stan, noting that Kyle's odd behavior began with the peace in the Middle East, seeks to investigate. Kyle and Cartman travel to Israel, where Cartman intends to further humiliate Kyle by having him endure his farts and claim to enjoy it on a stage before thousands of people. Their demonstration is interrupted, however, by a broadcast hosted by [[Anderson Cooper]], in which Stan intends to expose the truth about Cartman's red cow. Kyle, speaking to Stan privately by cell phone, explains why he has been enduring Cartman's abuse and convinces Stan not to expose the truth, in order to preserve the new peace. Acquiescing to this, Stan instead announces in the broadcast that he saw the cow descend [[miracle|miraculously]] from heaven. However, the prophecy stated that a fat child with a small penis would disguise a cow to look ginger, not that one would just miraculously fall from the sky. The short-lived peace among the three religions falls apart. Kyle, realizing that the prophecy really has occurred, tries to convince the rabbis that this is precisely what happened, but Cartman refuses to corroborate this. ==Production== ''South Park'' co-creators [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]] reveal on the DVD commentary for "Ginger Cow" the origin of the episode. Stone had been reading about how the [[red heifer]] relates to religions and thought they could make a big story about it; that big story ended up being about peace being brought to the Middle East since the red heifer had significance in several religions.{{cite video |people=[[Trey Parker|Parker, Trey]]; [[Matt Stone|Stone, Matt]] |date=2014 |title=South Park season 17 DVD commentary for the episode "Ginger Cow" |medium=DVD |publisher=[[Comedy Central]]}} Parker and Stone felt that, in hindsight, this episode should have been a two-part storyline. They said they thought they could have gotten a lot of mileage out of the main premise, with Parker even saying it could have potentially been a film. They were forced to cut a lot of content to condense the episode to the standard runtime of around twenty-one minutes. ==Reception== Max Nicholson of [[IGN]] gave the episode a score of 7.5 out of 10, stating that it "touches on some great ideas that would have benefited from more time".{{cite web|last=Nicholson|first=Max|title=ALL HAIL THE RED HEIFER!|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/11/07/south-park-ginger-cow-review|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=November 7, 2013}} Ryan McGee of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the episode a [[Academic grading in the United States|B+]] rating, stating: "'Ginger Cow' comes very close to utterly succeeding on several occasions, but ultimately settles for being fascinating. There are some great ideas here that no amount of screen time would ever sufficiently answer. But those ideas still needed more screen time to sufficiently ''debate''. Still, in a season as subpar as this has been, it’s heartening to see the show can still recapture some of its past heights this late in the game."{{cite web|last=McGee|first=Ryan|title=South Park "Ginger Cow"|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/south-park-ginger-cow-105222|publisher=''[[The A.V. Club]]''|date=November 6, 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.southparkstudios.com/full-episodes/s17e06-ginger-cow "Ginger Cow"] Full episode at South Park Studios. *{{IMDb episode|3237516}} *{{Tv.com episode|2991494}} {{South Park episodes|17}} [[Category:Christianity-related television episodes]] [[Category:Islam-related television episodes]] [[Category:Jewish comedy and humor]] [[Category:Jewish-related television episodes]] [[Category:South Park (season 17) episodes]] [[Category:Suicide in television]] [[Category:Van Halen]]

revision.comment: /* top */ italicize title; also, templates should not be substed arbitrarily
/* top */ Added two sentences to clarify ambiguous term "wireless communication network" - it was a network of high power radio stations that exchanged text messages in Morse code
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Use British English|date=May 2011}} [[File:The British Empire.png|thumb|The areas of the world that at one time were part of the [[British Empire]]. Current [[British overseas territories]] are underlined in red.]] The '''Imperial Wireless Chain''' was a strategic international communications network of powerful long range [[radiotelegraphy]] stations, created to link the countries of the [[British Empire]]. The stations exchanged commercial and diplomatic text message traffic transmitted at high speed by [[Morse code]] using [[punched paper tape|paper tape]] machines. Although the idea was conceived prior to [[World War I]], the United Kingdom was the last of the world's [[Great Powers|great powers]] to implement an operational system.<ref name=EP1923-04-23>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19230310.2.57&srpos=50 Empire Wireless] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1923-04-23, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> The first link in the chain, between [[Leafield]] in Oxfordshire and [[Cairo]], Egypt, eventually opened on 24 April 1922,<ref name=EP1921-11-21 /> with the final link, between Australia and Canada, opening on 16 June 1928.<ref name=EP28-06-16>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19280616.2.75.3&srpos=18 Beam Wireless] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1928-06-16, accessed 2010-10-03</ref>
==Initial scheme== [[File:Hillmorton radio masts.jpg|thumb|upright|Longwave masts at Rugby's [[Rugby radio station|Hillmorton transmitting station]] ([[:Image:Rugby radio masts.jpg|alternative view]])]]
[[Guglielmo Marconi]] invented the first practical [[radio transmitter]]s and [[radio receiver|receivers]], and radio began to be used for practical ship-to-shore communication around 1900. His company, the [[Marconi Company|Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company]], dominated early radio. In the period leading up to [[World War I]], long distance [[radiotelegraphy]] became a strategic defense technology, as it was realized that a nation without radio could be isolated by an enemy cutting its [[submarine telegraph cable]]s, as indeed happened during the war. Starting around 1908, industrialized nations built global networks of powerful transoceanic wireless telegraphy stations to exchange [[Morse code]] [[telegram]] traffic with their overseas colonies.<ref name="Headrick">{{cite book | last1 = Headrick | first1 = Daniel R. | title = The Tentacles of Progress : Technology Transfer in the Age of Imperialism, 1850-1940 | publisher = Oxford University Press | date = 1988 | location = New York | pages = 126-130 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0wjDxYlArQAC&pg=PA126 | doi = | id = | isbn = 019802178X }}</ref><ref name="Lescarboura">{{cite book | last1 = Lescarboura | first1 = Austin C. | title = Radio for Everybody | publisher = Scientific American Publishing Co. | date = 1922 | pages = 259-263 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pf0WAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA259 | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref>
In 1910 the [[Colonial Office]] received a formal proposal from the [[Marconi Company]] to construct a series of wireless telegraphy stations to link the British Empire within three years.<!--http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19090924.2.39&srpos=59--><ref name=EP1923-04-23 /> While not then accepted, the Marconi proposal created serious interest in the concept.<ref name=Hansard13-08-08>[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1913/aug/08/new-marconi-agreement New Marconi Agreement], Hansard, Published 1913-08-08, accessed 2010-10-03</ref>
A dilemma faced by Britain throughout the negotiations to establish the Chain was that Britain owned the largest network of [[submarine telegraph cable]]s. The proposed stations would directly compete with cables for a fixed amount of transoceanic telegram traffic, reducing the revenue of the cable companies and possibly bankrupting them.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
Parliament ruled out the creation of a private [[monopoly]] to provide the service and concluded that no government department was in a position to do so, and the Treasury were reluctant to fund the creation of a new department. Contracting the construction to a commercial "wireless company" was the favoured option,<ref name=Hansard13-08-08 /> and a contract was signed with Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company in March 1912. The government then found itself facing severe criticism and appointed a [[select committee (Westminster system)|select committee]] to examine the topic.<ref>[http://www.subbrit.org.uk/sb-sites/sites/r/rugby_radio/indexr67.shtml The Official History of Rugby Radio Station] Subterranea Britannica, Malcolm Hancock, accessed 2010-10-04</ref> After hearing evidence from the [[Admiralty]], [[War Office]], [[India Office]], and representatives from [[Union of South Africa|South Africa]], the committee unanimously concluded that a "chain of Imperial wireless stations" should be established as a matter of urgency.<ref name=Hansard13-08-08 /> An Expert Committee also advised that Marconi were the only company with technology that was proven to operate reliably over the distances required (in excess of {{convert|2000|mi}}) "if rapid installation and immediate and trustworthy communication be desired".<ref name=Hansard13-08-08 />
After further negotiations prompted by Treasury pressure, a modified contract was [[ratification|ratified]] by Parliament on 8 August 1913, with 221 [[Member of Parliament|Members of Parliament]] voting in favour, 140 against.<ref name=Hansard13-08-08 /> The course of these events was disrupted somewhat by the [[Marconi scandal]], when it was alleged that highly placed members of the governing [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] party had used their knowledge of the negotiations to indulge in [[insider trading]] in Marconi shares. The outbreak of [[World War I]] led to the suspension of the contract by the government.<ref name=Hansard24-08-01 /> Meanwhile Germany successfully constructed its own wireless chain before the war, at a cost equivalent to two million [[pound sterling|pounds sterling]], and was able to use it to its advantage during the conflict.<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19150911.2.120&srpos=32 The Wireless Chain] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1915-09-11, accessed 2010-10-03</ref>
==Post World War I== With the end of the war and the [[Dominion]]s continuing to apply pressure on the Government to provide an "Imperial wireless system",<ref name=Hansard24-08-01>[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1924/aug/01/post-office-contracts-marconi-wireless Post Office Contracts Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company, Limited] Hansard, 1924-08-01 , accessed 2010-10-03</ref> the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] agreed in 1919 that £170,000 should be spent constructing the first two radio stations in the chain, in Oxfordshire (at [[Leafield]]) and Egypt (in Cairo), to be completed in early 1920<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19190804.2.94.9&srpos=4 Wireless Chain] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1919-08-04, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> – although the link actually opened on 24 April 1922,<ref name=EP1921-11-21>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19220426.2.64.3&srpos=19 Wireless Service] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1921-11-21, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> two months after the UK [[Unilateral Declaration of Egyptian Independence|declared Egypt independent]].
Parliament's decision came shortly after legal action initiated by Marconi in June<!-- started in June, see Evening Post 6 June 1919 (although the sum claimed is incorrect) --> 1919, claiming £7,182,000 in damages from the British Government for [[breach of contract|breach of their July 1912 contract]], and in which they were awarded £590,000 by the court.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30A10F83D5C147A93C4AB178CD85F4D8185F9 Marconi Company Wins From Britain], New York Times, published 1919-07-26, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> The Government also commissioned the "Imperial Wireless Telegraphy Committee" chaired by [[Sir Henry Norman, 1st Baronet|Sir Henry Norman]] (the Norman Committee), which reported in 1920. The Norman Report recommended that transmitters should have a range of 2,000 miles, which required relay stations,<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19210716.2.29.2&srpos=29 Relays in the Wireless Line] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1921-07-16, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> and that Britain should be connected to [[Canada]], [[Australia]], [[South Africa]], Egypt, [[British Raj|India]], [[East Africa]], [[Singapore]], and [[Hong Kong]].<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19220127.2.38&srpos=39 Wireless Chain] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1922-01-27, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> However, the report was not acted upon.<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19210721.2.34 Wireless Links] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1921-07-21, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> While British politicians procrastinated, Marconi constructed stations for other nations, linking North and South America, as well as China and Japan, in 1922.<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19220816.2.51&srpos=9 New Wireless Services] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1922-08-16, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> In January 1922 the [[British Chambers of Commerce]] added their voice to the demands for action, adopting a resolution urging the Government to urgently resolve the matter,<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19230129.2.58.3&srpos=5 Link Up Wireless Chain] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1923-01-29, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> as did other organisations such as the [[Empire Press Union]], which claimed that the Empire was suffering "incalculable loss" in its absence.<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19221208.2.32.4&srpos=45 Radio Communication] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1922-12-08, accessed 2010-10-03</ref>
Under this pressure, after the [[United Kingdom general election, 1922|1922 General Election]], the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] government commissioned the Empire Wireless Committee, chaired by [[Robert Donald|Sir Robert Donald]], to "consider and advise upon the policy to be adopted as regards an Imperial wireless service so as to protect and facilitate public interest." Its report was presented to the Postmaster-General on 23 February 1924<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19240225.2.37.4&srpos=10 Empire Wireless] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1924-02-25, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> The committee's recommendations were similar to those of the Norman Committee – that any stations in Great Britain used to communicate with the Empire should be in the hands of the State, that they should be operated by the Post Office, and that eight high-power [[longwave]] stations should be used, as well as land-lines.<ref name=Hansard24-08-01 /><ref name=EP1926-11-20>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19261120.1.9] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1926-11-20, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> The scheme was estimated at £500,000.<ref name=EP1926-11-20 /> At the time the committee was unaware of Marconi's 1923 experiments into [[shortwave]] radio transmissions, which offered a much cheaper alternative – although not a commercially proven one – to high-power long-wave transmission system.<ref name=Hansard24-08-01 />
Following the Donald Report and discussions with the Dominions, it was decided that the high-power [[Rugby Radio Station|Rugby longwave station]] (announced on 13 July 1922 by the previous government)<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19230718.2.40&srpos=77 High Power Wireless] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1923-07-18, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> would be completed since it used proven technology, in addition to which a number of shortwave "beam stations" would be built (so called because a [[directional antenna]] concentrated the radio transmission into a narrow directional beam). The beam stations would communicate with those Dominions that chose the new shortwave technology. Parliament finally approved an agreement between the Post Office and Marconi to build beam stations to communicate with Canada, South Africa, India and Australia, on 1 August 1924.<ref name=Hansard24-08-01 />
==Commercial impact== From when the Post Office began operating the "Post Office Beam" services, through to March, 31st, 1929, they had earned gross receipts of £813,100 at a cost of £538,850, leaving a net surplus of £274,250.<ref name=Hansard29-07-22>[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1929/jul/22/beam-services#S5CV0230P0_19290722_CWA_62 Beam Services], Hansard, published 1929-07-22, accessed 2010-10-04</ref>
Even before the final link became operational between Australia and Canada, it was apparent that the commercial success of the Wireless Chain was threatening the viability of the [[Submarine communications cable|cable telegraphy]] companies. An "Imperial Wireless and Cable Conference" was therefore held in London in January 1928, with delegates from Great Britain, the self-governing Dominions, India, the Crown Colonies and Protectorates, to "examine the situation which arose as a result of the competition of the Imperial Beam Wireless Services with the cable services of various parts of the empire, to report upon it and to make recommendations with a view to a common policy being adopted by the various governments concerned."<ref>[http://openlibrary.org/show-records/marc_loc_updates/v35.i24.records.utf8:428615:1042 Imperial Wireless and Cable Conference] Library of Congress (Open Library), accessed 2010-10-04</ref> It concluded that the cable companies would not be able to compete in an unrestricted market, but that the cable links remained of both commercial and strategic value. It therefore recommended that the cable and wireless interests of the [[Eastern Telegraph Company]], the [[Eastern Extension, Australasia and China Telegraph Company]], [[Western Telegraph Company]] and Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company should be merged to form a single organisation holding a [[monopoly|monopolistic]] position. The merged company would be overseen by an Imperial Advisory Committee, would purchase the Government owned cables in the Pacific, West Indies and Atlantic, and would also be given a lease on the beam stations for a period of 25 years, for the sum of £250,000 per year.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article981898? Empire Communications - Cable and Wireless Merger] The Canberra Times, published 1928-07-28, accessed 2010-10-04</ref><ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19280710.2.45&l=mi An Important Development] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1928-07-10, accessed 2010-10-03</ref>
The conference's recommendations were incorporated into the [[Imperial Telegraphs Act 1929]], leading to the creation of two new companies on 8 April 1929; an operating company Imperial and International Communications, in turn owned by a holding company named [[Cable & Wireless Limited]]. In 1934 Imperial and International Communications was renamed as [[Cable & Wireless Worldwide|Cable & Wireless]] Limited, with Cable and Wireless Limited being renamed as Cable and Wireless (Holding) Limited.<ref name=jrankCW>[http://companies.jrank.org/pages/721/Cable-Wireless-Plc.html Cable And Wireless Plc Business Information, Profile, and History] jrank.org, accessed 2010-10-04</ref> From the beginning of April 1928 the Beam services were operated by the Post Office as [[Law of agency|agent]] for Imperial and International Communications Limited.<ref name=Hansard29-07-22 />
==Transfers of ownership== The 1930s saw the arrival of the [[Great Depression]], as well as competition from the [[ITT Corporation|International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation]] and affordable [[airmail]]. Due to such factors Cable and Wireless were never able to earn the revenue which had been forecast, resulting in low dividends and an inability to reduce the rates charged to customers as much as had been expected.<ref name=Hansard38-05-10>[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1938/may/30/imperial-telegraphs-bill#S5CV0336P0_19380530_HOC_280 Imperial Telegraphs Bill] Hansard, published 1938-05-30, accessed 2010-10-04</ref> To ease the financial pressure, the British Government finally decided to transfer the beam stations to Cable and Wireless, in exchange for 2,600,000 of the 30,000,000 [[Share (finance)|shares]] in the company, under the provisions of the [[Imperial Telegraphs Act 1938]].<ref name=jrankCW /><ref name=Hansard38-05-10 /> The ownership of the beam stations was reversed in 1947, when the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] Government nationalised Cable and Wireless, integrating its UK assets with those of the Post Office.<ref>[http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/CandW/CW/ History of the Atlantic Cable & Submarine Telegraphy - Cable & Wireless] Bill Glover, accessed 2010-10-04</ref> By this stage, however, three of the original stations had been closed, after the service was centralised during 1939–1940 at Dorchester and Somerton.<ref name=Tetney /> The longwave Rugby radio station continued to remain under Post Office ownership throughout.{{cn|date = April 2014}}
==Beam stations== [[File:Moosbrunn SW Antenna.jpg|thumb|250px|A much smaller, more recent shortwave "curtain antenna" (unconnected with the Imperial Wireless Chain) illustrates the principle]] The shortwave Imperial Wireless Chain "beam stations" operated in pairs; one transmitting and one receiving. Pairs of stations were sited at (transmitters first):<ref name=Tetney>[http://tetneybeamstation.blogspot.com/ Tetney Beam Station], Paul Hewitt, Tetney County Primary School, published 2005-09-24, accessed 2010-10-04</ref> *[[Tetney]] and [[Winthorpe, Lincolnshire|Winthorpe]] (with [[Ballan, Victoria|Ballan]] and [[Rockbank, Victoria|Rockbank]] in Australia, and with [[Khadki]] and [[Daund]] in India) *[[Chipping Ongar|Ongar]] and [[Brentwood, Essex|Brentwood]] *[[Dorchester, Dorset|Dorchester]] and [[Somerton, Somerset|Somerton]] *[[Bodmin]] and [[Bridgwater]] – the latter actually in the hamlet of [[Huntworth]] which is nearer to [[North_Petherton#History|North Petherton]] (with [[Drummondville]] and [[Yamachiche, Quebec|Yamachiche]] in Canada,<ref name=Beam29-10-05>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19270105.2.51&l=mi Beam Wireless] Papers Past, Evening Post (New Zealand), published 1927-10-05, accessed 2010-10-03</ref> and with Kliphevel (now [[Klipheuwel]]) and [[Milnerton]] in South Africa)<ref>[http://mt-shortwave.blogspot.com/2010/11/beam-wireless-original-stations.html Beam Wireless - The Original Stations] Shortwave Central, published 2010-11-30, accessed 2011,03-06</ref>
At Bodmin and Bridgwater, each aerial stretched to nearly half a mile (800 m) long, and consisted of a row of five {{convert|277|ft}} high [[lattice tower|lattice masts]], erected in a line at {{convert|640|ft}} intervals and at right angles to the overseas receiving station. These were topped by cross-arm measuring {{convert|10|ft}} high by {{convert|90|ft}} wide, from which the vertical wires of the aerial were hung, forming a "[[curtain antenna]]".<ref name=Beam29-10-05 /> At Tetney the antenna for India was similar to those at Bodmin and Bridgwater, while the Australian aerial was carried on three {{convert|275|ft}} high masts.<ref name=Tetney />
Electronic components for the system were built at Marconi's New Street wireless factory in [[Chelmsford]].<ref>[http://homepages.tesco.net/~martin.batesuk/marconi/sections_added_1912-1980.htm The Marconi Company Departments 1912 - 1970] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101020155019/http://homepages.tesco.net/~martin.batesuk/marconi/sections_added_1912-1980.htm |date=20 October 2010 }} Martin Bates, accessed 2010-10-04</ref>
[[Devizes wireless station|Devizes]] was home to a receiving station until the outbreak of [[World War One]].{{cn|date=April 2018}}
==See also== *[[Marconi Station]] *[[History of radio]] *[[Telecommunication]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://tetneybeamstation.blogspot.com/ Tetney Beam Station] – Tetney County Primary School *[http://www.g3sds.org.uk/beamstat.htm Dorchester Radio Station] – South Dorset Radio Society

This is a list of '''[[Laos]]''''s representatives and their placements at the [[beauty contest#Around the globe|'''Big Four''' international beauty pageants]], considered the most important in the world. The country has not yet win any crown: ''The criteria for the [[Big Four international beauty pageants|Big Four]] inclusion are based on specific standards such as the pageant's global prominence and prestige approved by worldwide media; the quality and quantity of crowned delegates recognized by international franchisees and pageant aficionados; the winner's post pageant activities; the pageant's longevity, consistency, and history; the sincerity of the pageant's specific cause, platform, and advocacy; the overall pre-pageant activities, production quality and global telecast; the enormity of internet traffic; and the extent of popularity amongst pageant fans across the globe.{{cite web |url=http://www.sashfactor.info/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=2004 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021190715/http://www.sashfactor.info/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=2004 |archivedate=2014-10-21 |df= }}International Beauty Pageant Ranking{{cite web |url=http://missosology.org/big4/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014111825/http://missosology.org/big4/ |archivedate=2014-10-14 |df= }} ==Laos's Big Four titleholders== ;Color key {{plainlist| * {{Color box|#FFFF66|border=darkgray}} Ended as runner-up * {{Color box|#FFFACD|border=darkgray}} Ended as one of the finalists or semifinalists }} {| class="wiki table" border="3" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0 1em 0 0; background: white; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 90%;" |- ! bgcolor="#E4E4EA" width=5%| YEAR ! bgcolor="#FF1493" width=15%| [[Miss Universe|MISS UNIVERSE]] ! bgcolor="#6495ED" width=15%| [[Miss World|MISS WORLD]] ! bgcolor="#DDA0DD" width=15%| [[Miss International|MISS INTERNATIONAL]] ! bgcolor="#90EE90" width=15%| [[Miss Earth|MISS EARTH]] |- | align="center" |2018 | align="center" |On-anong Homsombath

revision.comment: New productions mentioned. Ticket success mentioned. Source: https://www.radiobremen.de/bremenzwei/rubriken/theater/lazarus-ueberall100-popup.html
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox musical |name=Lazarus |image=Lazarus-poster.png |caption=Off-Broadway promotional poster |music= [[David Bowie]] |lyrics= David Bowie |book= [[Enda Walsh]] |basis= ''[[The Man Who Fell to Earth]]''
by [[Walter Tevis]] |productions={{plainlist| *2015 [[Off-Broadway]] *2016 [[Off West End|Off-West End]]}} |awards= }} '''''Lazarus''''' is a musical with music and lyrics composed by [[David Bowie]], and a book written by [[Enda Walsh]]. First performed at the end of 2015, it was one of the last works Bowie completed before [[Death of David Bowie|his death]] on 10 January 2016. The musical is inspired by [[Walter Tevis]]'s novel ''[[The Man Who Fell to Earth (novel)|The Man Who Fell to Earth]]''. Bowie previously starred in the [[The Man Who Fell to Earth (film)|1976 film adaptation of the same name]], directed by [[Nicolas Roeg]]. As of September 2018 there have been five productions: one each in New York, London, Bremen, Düsseldorf, and Vienna. Six further productions are planned for Leipzig, Hamburg, Linz, Amsterdam, Bielefeld and Göttingen. All of the productions have been box-office successes. ==New York production== ===Production details=== The musical was staged for a limited run at [[New York Theatre Workshop]] in [[Manhattan]], directed by [[Ivo van Hove]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/17/fashion/david-bowie-invisible-new-yorker.html|title=David Bowie: Invisible New Yorker|date=16 January 2016| accessdate=18 January 2016|first=Steven|last=Kurutz|work=[[The New York Times]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lortel.org/Archives/Production/6058|title=''Lazarus'' – Lortel Archives|publisher=}} Like Bowie's contemporary album ''[[Blackstar (album)|Blackstar]]'' (with which it shares the song "[[Lazarus (David Bowie song)|Lazarus]]"),{{cite web | url=http://hollandude.com/producer-tony-visconti-talks-david-bowie-and-blackstar/ | title=Producer Tony Visconti Talks David Bowie and ''Blackstar'' | journal=Hollandude | date=6 January 2016 | accessdate=12 January 2016 | first=Eric|last=Holland}} much of the production of the musical was kept secret until its first preview in November 2015. The musical opened on 7 December 2015{{cite web | url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/123938/20160113/broadway-play-lazarus-david-bowies-swan-song.htm | title=Off-Broadway Play ''Lazarus'' Is David Bowie's Swan Song | accessdate=18 January 2016 | date=13 January 2016 | first=Jan | last=Dizon | journal=Tech Times}} with a planned run through 17 January 2016,{{cite web | url=http://playbill.com/news/article/david-bowies-lazarus-opens-off-broadway-tonight-374294 | title=David Bowie's ''Lazarus'' Opens Off-Broadway Tonight | first=Olivia | last=Clement | date=7 December 2015 | accessdate=18 January 2016}} although the production was extended to 20 January 2016.{{cite web | url=http://movies.ndtv.com/music/new-york-declares-david-bowie-day-as-final-play-ends-1268218 | title=New York Declares 'David Bowie Day' as Final Play Ends | date=21 January 2016 | accessdate=25 January 2016}} Tickets to the entire run of the musical sold out within hours of being made available.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/tickets-to-david-bowies-lazarus-sell-out-within-hours-366100 | title=Tickets to David Bowie's ''Lazarus'' Sell Out Within Hours | first=Olivia | last=Clement | date=7 October 2015 | accessdate=18 January 2016}} ===Cast=== *[[Michael C. Hall]] as Thomas Jerome Newton. *[[Cristin Milioti]] as Newton's assistant, Elly.{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/news/cristin-milioti-on-fargo-david-bowie-and-that-himym-finale-20160301 | title=Cristin Milioti on ''Fargo'', David Bowie and That ''HIMYM'' Finale | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=1 March 2016 | accessdate=2 March 2016 | first=Kory | last=Grow}} *[[Sophia Anne Caruso]] as Newton's muse.{{cite web |first=Kory | last=Grow | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/david-bowies-lazarus-is-surrealistic-tour-de-force-20151207 | title=David Bowie's ''Lazarus'' Is Surrealistic Tour de Force | work=[[Rolling Stone]]| publisher=Wenner Media LLC|location=New York City|date=December 7, 2015 | accessdate=March 2, 2016 }} *[[Michael Esper]] as Valentine. *[[Alan Cumming]] as the girl's killer (video insert){{cite web|first=Miriam|last=Felton-Dansk|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/arts/the-man-who-fell-to-earth-rises-again-in-lazarusor-does-he-7999996|title=The Man Who Fell to Earth Rises Again in ''Lazarus''...Or Does He?|work=[[The Village Voice]]|publisher=VF Media|location=New York City|date=December 8, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2016}} ===Notable events=== Bowie's last public appearance was at the 7 December 2015 opening night of the production.{{cite web | url=http://people.com/celebrity/david-bowies-final-public-appearance-before-death/ | title=Bowie's final public appearance | accessdate=1 November 2016}} New York City's mayor's office declared the final day of the play's run (20 January 2016) "David Bowie Day" in honour of the late artist and presented the proclamation to managing director Jeremy Blocker at the curtain call of the final show.{{cite web | url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2016/01/20/mayors-office-declares-wednesday-david-bowie-day/ | title=Mayor's Office Declares Wednesday 'David Bowie Day' | date=20 January 2016 | accessdate=25 January 2016 | journal=CBS Local – New York}} ===Critical reception=== [[Ben Brantley]] said in his review of the production in ''[[The New York Times]]'' that "Ice-bolts of ecstasy shoot like novas through the fabulous muddle and murk of ''Lazarus'', the great-sounding, great-looking and mind numbing new musical built around songs by David Bowie."{{cite web|first=Ben|last=Brantley|authorlink=Ben Brantley|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/08/theater/review-david-bowie-songs-and-a-familiar-alien-in-lazarus.html|title=Review: David Bowie Songs and a Familiar Alien in ‘Lazarus’|work=The New York Times|date=December 8, 2015|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' called the musical a "tour de force" and "theater at its finest." ==London production== ===Production details=== A London production of the musical was announced in July 2016. The London production ran at the [[Kings Cross Theatre]] from 8 November 2016 to 22 January 2017, with previews beginning the week of 25 October.{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-36883217 | title=David Bowie musical ''Lazarus'' to open in London | date=25 July 2016 | accessdate=25 July 2016 |publisher=[[BBC]]}}{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/full-cast-announced-david-bowie-lazarus-amy-lennox_41787.html | title=Full cast announced for David Bowie's ''Lazarus''| work=WhatsOnStage.com | date=15 September 2016 | accessdate=15 September 2016 | first=Will | last=Longman}} Ivo van Hove directed the London production.{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/26/theater/lazarus-david-bowie-enda-walsh-london.html?_r=0 | title=''Lazarus'', a Musical by David Bowie and Enda Walsh, to Open in London | date=25 July 2016 | accessdate=25 July 2016 | first=Christopher | last=Shea | journal=New York Times}} The London production was produced by Robert Fox Ltd. and Jones/Tintoretto Entertainment.{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/david-bowies-lazarus-musical-sets-914147 | title=It's Official: David Bowie's ''Lazarus'' Musical Sets London Run | date=25 July 2016 | accessdate=25 July 2016 | first=Ashley | last=Lee |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}} ===Cast=== *Michael C. Hall as Thomas Jerome Newton *[[Amy Lennox]] as Newton's assistant, Elly *Sophia Anne Caruso as Newton's muse *Michael Esper as Valentine *[[Jamie Muscato]] as Ben Additional cast members: *[[Gabrielle Brooks]] *[[Sydnie Christmas]] *[[Richard Hansell]] *[[Maimuna Memon]] *[[Tom Parsons (actor)|Tom Parsons]] *[[Julie Yammanee]] ===Notable events=== A performance in London was recorded for a ''Lazarus'' film; the film was shown in New York for one night in May, 2018.{{cite web | url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/musicnews/david-bowie%E2%80%99s-lazarus-rises-again-in-brooklyn/ar-AAwDYox | title=David Bowie’s Lazarus Rises Again in Brooklyn | date=2 May 2018 | accessdate=8 May 2018 | first=Corey | last=Seymour | work=Vogue}} ==Songs== ''Lazarus'' features a number of songs from Bowie's back catalogue as well as four new tracks ("Lazarus", "No Plan", "Killing a Little Time", "When I Met You").{{cite web | url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/david-bowies-lazarus-musical-song-titles-revealed-71997 | title=David Bowie's ''Lazarus'' musical: song titles revealed | date=8 December 2015 | accessdate=19 January 2016 | journal=[[Uncut (magazine)|''Uncut'']] | first=Michael | last=Bonner}} {{Track listing | collapsed = | headline = | extra_column = Original album | all_writing = [[David Bowie]], except where noted | all_lyrics = | all_music = | writing_credits = | lyrics_credits = | music_credits = | title1 = [[Lazarus (David Bowie song)|Lazarus]] | extra1 = ''[[Blackstar (album)|Blackstar]]'' (2016) | title2 = [[It's No Game|It's No Game (Part 1)]] | extra2 = ''[[Scary Monsters (And Super Creeps)|Scary Monsters]]'' (1980) | title3 = [[This Is Not America]] | extra3 = ''[[The Falcon and the Snowman (album)|The Falcon and the Snowman]]'' (1985) | note3 = written by Bowie, [[Pat Metheny]] and [[Lyle Mays]] | title4 = [[The Man Who Sold the World]] | extra4 = ''[[The Man Who Sold the World (album)|The Man Who Sold the World]]'' (1970) | note4 = | title5 = No Plan | extra5 = ''[[No Plan (EP)|No Plan]]'' (2017) | title6 = [[Love Is Lost]] | extra6 = ''[[The Next Day]]'' (2013) | title7 = [[Changes (David Bowie song)|Changes]] | extra7 = ''[[Hunky Dory]]'' (1971) | title8 = [[Where Are We Now?]] | extra8 = ''The Next Day'' (2013) | title9 = [[Absolute Beginners (David Bowie song)|Absolute Beginners]] | extra9 = ''[[Absolute Beginners: The Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|Absolute Beginners]]'' (1986) | title10 = Dirty Boys | extra10 = ''The Next Day'' (2013) | title11 = Killing A Little Time | extra11 = ''No Plan'' (2017) | title12 = [[Life on Mars (song)|Life on Mars?]] | extra12 = ''Hunky Dory'' (1971) | title13 = [[All the Young Dudes]] | extra13 = ''[[All the Young Dudes (album)|All the Young Dudes]]'' (1972) | title14 = [[Sound and Vision]] | extra14 = ''[[Low (David Bowie album)|Low]]'' (1977) | title15 = [[Always Crashing in the Same Car]] | extra15 = ''Low'' (1977) | title16 = [[Valentine's Day (David Bowie song)|Valentine's Day]] | extra16 = ''The Next Day'' (2013) | title17 = When I Met You | extra17 = ''No Plan'' (2017) | title18 = [["Heroes" (David Bowie song)|"Heroes"]] | extra18 = ''[["Heroes" (David Bowie album)|"Heroes"]]'' (1977) | note18 = written by Bowie and [[Brian Eno]] }} ==Original cast recording== On 21 October 2016, the original cast recording, ''[[Lazarus (soundtrack)|Lazarus]]'', was released. The album also features three previously unreleased songs from Bowie, among the last he recorded prior to his death. ==Awards and nominations== ===Original Off-Broadway production=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:5%;"| Year ! style="width:20%;"| Award ! style="width:45%;"| Category ! style="width:20%;"| Nominee ! style="width:10%;"| Outcome |- | rowspan="11" style="text-align:center;"| 2016 | rowspan="3"| [[Drama Desk Award]]s | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actor in a Musical|Outstanding Actor in a Musical]] | [[Michael C. Hall]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Sound Design in a Musical|Outstanding Sound Design in a Musical]] | Brian Ronan | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Projection Design|Outstanding Projection Design]] | Tal Yarden | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama League Award]]s | Distinguished Performance | Michael C. Hall | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="5"| [[Outer Critics Circle Award]]s | colspan="2"| Outstanding New Off-Broadway Musical | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Book of a Musical (Broadway or Off-Broadway) | [[Enda Walsh]] | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Featured Actor in a Musical | [[Michael Esper]] | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical | [[Sophia Anne Caruso]] | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Projection Design (Play or Musical) | Tal Yarden | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[Lucille Lortel Awards]] | Outstanding Lead Actor in a Musical | Michael C. Hall | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Lead Actress in a Musical | Sophia Anne Caruso | {{nom}} |} ===Original Off-West End production=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:5%;"| Year ! style="width:20%;"| Award ceremony ! style="width:45%;"| Category ! style="width:20%;"| Nominee ! style="width:10%;"| Result |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"| 2017 | rowspan="4"| [[WhatsOnStage Awards]] | Best Actor in a Musical | Michael C. page.title: List of entertainment events at The Forum

revision.text:
{{main article|The Forum (Inglewood, California)}} This article shows a list of entertainment events that were held at '''[[The Forum (Inglewood, California)|The Forum]]''' in [[Inglewood, California]], United States. The busiest music arena in the [[Los Angeles area]] has hosted many local, regional and international artists since its opening in late-1967. A list of entertainment events are given in the tables below in a chronological order. [[The Rolling Stones]] set a record-breaking gross in 1969 from two shows with a total gross of $238,000 which was later surpassed by [[Elvis Presley]] in late-1970 with a total gross of $313,000.{{citeweb|url=http://www.elvisconcerts.com/newspapers/press294.htm|title=Elvis Presley|accessdate=October 22, 2016}} == 1969 - present == {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" |- ! colspan="3"|Entertainment events at The Forum |- ! width=50| Date ! width=100| Artists ! width=150| Events |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan=3| 1969 |- | November 8{{efn|Two shows were held on November 8.}} | [[The Rolling Stones]] | [[The Rolling Stones American Tour 1969]] |- ! colspan="3" |1970 |- | August 17 | rowspan=2| [[Stephen Stills]] |- | August 18 |- | November 14{{citeweb|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-adv-forum-legacy-pictures-photogallery.html|title=Concerts at The Forum|publisher=[[L.A. Times]]|accessdate=October 22, 2016}} | [[Elvis Presley]] | {{n/a}} |- ! colspan="3"|1974 |- | February 13{{efn|Two shows were held on February 14, an afternoon and an evening show.}} | rowspan=3| [[Bob Dylan]] | rowspan=3| 1974 Tour of America with the Band{{citeweb|url=http://www.bjorner.com/CH%20Los%20Angeles,%20California.htm|title=Bob Dylan concerts in Los Angeles|accessdate=October 22, 2016}} |- | February 14 |- | February 18 |- | May 11 | [[Elvis Presley]]{{cite web|url=http://www.elvispresleymusic.com.au/pictures/1974-may-11.html|title=Elvis: May 11, 1974|accessdate=October 22, 2016}} | {{n/a}} |- ! colspan="3"|1975 |- | July 9 | rowspan=5| [[The Rolling Stones]] | rowspan=5| [[The Rolling Stones' Tour of the Americas '75]] |- | July 10 |- | July 11 |- | July 12 |- | July 13 |- ! colspan="3"|1977 |- | March 2 | rowspan=2| [[Queen (band)|Queen]] | rowspan=2| [[A Day At The Races Tour]] |- | March 3 |- | June 26 | [[Led Zeppelin]] | {{n/a}} |- | August 29 | [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]] | {{n/a}} |- | December 22 | [[Queen (band)|Queen]] | [[News of the World Tour]] |- ! colspan="3"|1978 |- | July 5 | [[Bruce Springsteen]] | [[Darkness Tour]] |- | November 15 | [[Bob Dylan]] | 1978 World Tour |- | October 24 | [[Neil Young]] | {{n/a}} |- | December 18 | rowspan=3| [[Queen (band)|Queen]] | rowspan=3| [[Jazz Tour]] |- | December 19 |- | December 20 |- |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan="3" |1980 |- | March 1 | [[The Eagles (band)|The Eagles]] | {{n/a}} |- | July 8 | rowspan=4| [[Queen (band)|Queen]] | rowspan=4| [[The Game Tour]] |- | July 9 |- | July 11 |- | July 12 |- ! colspan="3"|1981 |- | December 21 | [[Earth, Wind & Fire]] | {{n/a}} |- ! colspan="3"|1982 |- | September 14 | rowspan=2| [[Queen (band)|Queen]] | rowspan=2| [[Hot Space Tour]] |- | September 15 |- ! colspan="3"|1983 |- | March 29 | [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] | [[1999 Tour]] |- | September 11 | [[Def Leppard]] | Live - L.A.
