{{Infobox court case |name = Reference Re Alberta Statutes |court = [[Judicial Committee of the Privy Council]] |image = |imagesize = |imagelink = |imagealt = |caption = |full name = Attorney General of Alberta v Attorney General of Canada |date decided = {{Start date|1938|07|14}} |citations = |transcripts = |judges = [[Viscount Maugham|The Lord Chancellor]], [[James Atkin, Baron Atkin|Lord Atkin]], [[William Watson, Baron Thankerton|Lord Thankerton]], [[Frank Russell, Baron Russell of Killowen|Lord Russell of Killowen]], [[Hugh Macmillan, Baron Macmillan|Lord Macmillan]] |number of judges = 5 |decision by = [[Viscount Maugham|The Lord Chancellor]] |prior actions = |appealed from = {{cite CanLII|litigants=Reference Re Alberta Statutes - The Bank Taxation Act; The Credit of Alberta Regulation Act; and the Accurate News and Information Act|link=|year=1938|court=scc|num=1|format=canlii|pinpoint=|parallelcite=[1938] SCR 100|date=4 March 1938|courtname=auto|juris=}} |appealed to = |subsequent actions = |related actions = |opinions = |keywords = <!-- {{flatlist|}} --> |italic title = }} '''''Reference Re Alberta Statutes''''',<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants=Attorney General of Alberta v Attorney General of Canada|link=|court=UKPC|year=1938|num=46|para=|format=1|parallelcite=|date=14 July 1938|courtname=[[Judicial Committee of the Privy Council|P.C.]]|juris=Canada}}</ref> also known as the '''Alberta Press case''' and the '''Alberta Press Act Reference''', is a landmark [[reference question|reference]] of the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] where several provincial laws, including one restricting the press, were struck down and the existence of an [[implied bill of rights]] protecting civil liberties such as a free press was first proposed.
==Background==
The province of [[Alberta]], under the [[Social Credit]] government of [[William Aberhart]] had passed several laws as part of a series of reforms inspired by [[social credit]] economic theory. Arising from the [[1937 Social Credit backbenchers' revolt]], the [[Legislative Assembly of Alberta]] passed several Acts to implement the Social Credit agenda, to which [[royal assent]] was given:
:* ''Credit of Alberta Regulation Act''<ref>SA 1937 (2nd Sess.), c. 1</ref> (requiring all bankers to obtain a license from the Social Credit Commission) :* ''Bank Employees Civil Rights Act''<ref>SA 1937 (2nd Sess.), c. 2</ref> (preventing unlicensed banks and their employees from initiating civil actions) :* ''Judicature Act Amendment Act''<ref>SA 1937 (2nd Sess.), c. 5</ref> (preventing any person from challenging the constitutionality of Alberta's laws in court without receiving the approval of the [[Lieutenant-Governor in Council]])
In August 1937, the federal government [[Disallowance and reservation|disallowed]] all three Acts. The [[Supreme Court of Canada]], in answering [[reference question]]s posed by the federal government, unanimously ruled that such disallowance was valid.<ref>{{cite CanLII|litigants=Reference re The Power of the Governor General in Council to Disallow Provincial Legislation and the Power of Reservation of a Lieutenant-Governor of a Province|link=|year=1938|court=scc|num=34|format=canlii|pinpoint=|parallelcite=[1938] SCR 71|date=4 March 1938|courtname=auto|juris=}}</ref>
Following the disallowance, the Alberta legislature passed the following bills in October 1937:
:* Bill No. 1 ''Bank Taxation Act'' (levying provincial taxes on banks' paid-up capital and reserve funds at punitive rates) :* Bill No. 8 ''Credit of Alberta Regulation Act, 1937'' (similar to the previous disallowed Act, but covering all "credit institutions") :* Bill No. 9 ''[[Accurate News and Information Act]]'' (requiring newspapers to print "clarifications" of stories considered inaccurate by the [[Social Credit Board]], and to reveal their sources on demand, and also authorizing the provincial government to prohibit the publication of any newspaper, any article by a given writer, or any article making use of a given source)
All bills were [[Disallowance and reservation|reserved]] by Lieutenant-Governor [[John C. Bowen]]. As a result, the federal government posed the following [[reference question]]s to the Supreme Court as to whether it was ''[[intra vires]]'' the provincial legislature to pass any of those measures.
==Reference to the Supreme Court of Canada==
All six members of the Court declared the subject matter of all the bills as ''[[ultra vires]]'' the province. In addition, the Court ruled 5-0 ([[Lawrence Arthur Dumoulin Cannon|Cannon J]] expressing no opinion) that the ''Alberta Social Credit Act''<ref>SA 1937 (1st Sess.), c. 10</ref> was unconstitutional as well, as it attempted to intrude on the federal powers relating to [[currency]], banks and banking, and [[trade and commerce]].
As to the ''[[Accurate News and Information Act]]'', five of the six justices stated that, since the press bill was ancillary to the ''Alberta Social Credit Act'' which had been ruled ''ultra vires'', the press bill was automatically as well, while Cannon J considered the subject matter of the bill to be solely under federal jurisdiction. In their concurring opinion for the majority, [[Lyman Poore Duff|Duff CJ]] and [[Henry Hague Davis|Davis J]] argued that press freedom was too important to be left entirely to the provinces. The three judges argued that the [[Preamble to the Constitution Act, 1867|preamble]] of the ''[[Constitution Act, 1867|British North America Act, 1867]]'', which states that Canada has a constitution similar to that of the United Kingdom, implies that freedom of the press is vital to Canada's democratic system.
==Appeal to the Privy Council==
The Board declared that, as the ''Alberta Social Credit Act'' had been subsequently repealed by the Alberta legislature,<ref>SA 1938, c. 4</ref> Bills 8 and 9 could not be brought into operation, as their provisions were contingent on actions of the now-abolished Social Credit Board. Therefore, the question was [[mootness|moot]], and they expressed no opinion on them.
As to Bill 1, the Board agreed with the opinion of [[Patrick Kerwin|Kerwin J]] (concurred in by [[Oswald Smith Crocket|Crocket J]]) that:
{{Quotation| The sequence of events after the disallowance of the three Acts is so significant that I can find no escape from the conclusion that, instead of being a taxing enactment, Bill 1 is merely a part of a legislative plan to prevent the operation within the province of those banking institutions which have been called into existence and given the necessary powers to conduct their business by the only proper authority, the Parliament of Canada.<ref>SCC reference, at p. 151</ref>}}
Accordingly, the bill was in [[pith and substance]] a measure to regulate banking, and was thus ''ultra vires'' the province.
==Significance==
The SCC ruling was one of the foundation cases leading to the recognition of an [[Implied Bill of Rights]] in Canadian constitutional law.
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{multiple issues| {{POV|date=February 2014}} {{more citations needed|date=February 2014}} }}
[[File:Nirma auto.jpg|thumb|Robocon India 2013]] [[File:Robocon India 2010.jpg|thumb|Robocon India 2010]]
'''Robocon''' (short for Robotic Contest) is organised by [[Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union]] (ABU), a collection of over 20 countries of Asia Pacific Region. NHK, Japan had already been organising such contests at national level and also became the host of the first ABU Robocon in 2002. Since then, every year one of the member broadcasters hosts this international event. [[File:Robocon arena.jpg|thumb|Robocon India 2009 View of Arena]] The broadcasters of each participant country are responsible for conduct of their national contests to select the team which will represent their country in the International Contest. Teams from Engineering and Technological colleges are eligible for participation. Participating Teams are expected to design and fabricate their own robots and organize their teams including an Instructor, Team Leader, Manual Robot Operator and an Automatic Robot Operator.
==National Contest==
[[File:Into the field of dreams.jpg|thumb|On the way to arena.. to fight!!]] [[Doordarshan]], the national public service broadcaster organises National Robocon event every year and the winning team gets an opportunity to represent India at the international competition. First Robocon was held in 2002, in which only 3 teams had participated at [[IIT Kanpur]]. Going from strength to strength, this number has reached 66 in Indian National Robocon 2012 and 107 in 2018 held at the Boxing Arena of [[Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex]], Balewadi, Pune. [[File:Robocon-2010.jpg|thumb|View of Robocon 2010 arena]] Mumbai Kendra of Doordarshan has been organising National Robocon since 2005 with support from co hosts MIT Group of Educational Institutes. The initiative was taken by Mr Mukesh Sharma, the Director of Doordarshan Kendra Mumbai and Dr Sunil Karad, Executive Director of MIT Group of Institutions Pune, with approval of Dr Vishwanath D Karad, Founding Director General of MIT Group Pune.
Every year finals of Robocon India are held on First Saturday of March. The best engineering institutes across the country compete with each other for the honour of representing Indian National team at the International version of the competition for 3 gruelling days. Elimination rounds are held on days preceding the First Saturday of March. This routine schedule been fixed in India through mutual consultations of participating colleges and Doordarshan of India. International Contests are held in August every year when the national contests of all the countries have been completed and their representatives selected. The host country has the privilege of fielding two teams. India hosted its first international contest in August 2008 in the MIT Sports grounds, Pune. In 2014 again, India hosted the international contest on August 24. For last four years the National Robotics Championship has been organized in the famous Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex, Mahalunge, Balewadi, Pune by a joint collaboration of Doordarshan and [[Maharashtra Academy of Engineering|Maharashtra Institute of Technology Academy Of Engineering (MITAOE)]], Alandi, Pune.
Being the leading broadcaster in India, Doordarshan has been instrumental in providing wide coverage and public reach to Robocon.
== Recent Competitions ==
=== Robocon India 2018 === The National ABU Robocon 2018 was held in the Badminton Hall of the Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex, Balewadi, Pune on the 1-3 March 2018. The theme for Robocon 2018 declared as ''ném còn'' (throwing shuttlecock). The goal of the game is to throw the shuttlecocks through the ring at height. In Vietnamese culture, the game is about celebration and making friendship.<ref>{{Citation|title=ABU Robocon|date=2018-11-22|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ABU_Robocon&oldid=870125910|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref> [[File:Robocon India 2018 held at Pune.jpg|alt=|thumb|Robocon India 2018]] Institute of Technology, [[Nirma University]], Ahmedabad won the National ABU Robocon 2018 Contest. [[Maharashtra Institute of Technology]], [[Pune]], was the first runner-up and [[K. J. Somaiya Institute of Engineering and Information Technology|K J Somaiya Institute of Engineering and Information Technology, Mumbai]], was the second runner up. [[Lalbhai_Dalpatbhai_College_of_Engineering|L D Engineering College, Ahmedabad]] won the best idea award.<ref name="roboconindia.com" />
=== Robocon India 2017 === [[File:Robocon India 2017 Arena View.jpg|thumb|Robocon India 2017...Finals is about to began.]] The National ABU Robocon 2017 took place in the Shri Shiv Chhatrapati Krida Sankul, Pune on 2–4 March 2017. The contest theme has been declared as "Asobi : The Landing Disc”. [[College of Engineering, Pune]] won the National ABU Robocon 2017 Contest. [[Maharashtra Institute of Technology]], [[Pune]], was the first runner-up.<ref name="roboconindia.com">http://www.roboconindia.com/index.php/history</ref>
=== Robocon India 2016 === The National ABU Robocon 2016 took place in the Shri Shiv Chhatrapati Krida Sankul, Pune on 3–5 March 2016. The theme for Robocon 2016 has been declared as 'Chai-Yo : Clean Energy Recharging the World'. Vadodara Institute of Engineering, Vadodara won the National ABU Robocon 2016 Contest.<ref name="roboconindia.com"/> [[College of Engineering, Pune]], was the first runner-up.
=== Robocon India 2015 === The National ABU Robocon 2015 took place in the Badminton Hall of the Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex, Balewadi, Pune on 7 March 2015. The theme for Robocon 2015 has been declared by [[TVRI|Televisi Republik Indonesia (TVRI)]] as "Robomintion: Badmintion Robo-Game".<ref>http://www.roboconindia.com/index.php/theme-and-story</ref> Institute of Technology, [[Nirma University of Science and Technology|Nirma University]], Gujarat won the National ABU Robocon 2015 Contest. Krishna Institute Of Engineering And Technology (KIET), Ghaziabad were the first runners-up.Muffakham Jah College of Engineering and Technology (MJCET) stood 3rd in the country and was also awarded the ‘Best Design and Aesthetics’ robot at the Asia Pacific Broadcasting Union Robotics Contest (ABU Robocon) 2015 held at Maharashtra Institute of Technology, Pune.
=== Robocon India 2014 === The National ABU Robocon 2014 was held in the Badminton Hall of the Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex, Balewadi, Pune on the 6, 7 & 8 March 2014. The theme for Robocon 2014 declared by MITAOE was [http://www.roboconindia.com/#!/theme_story "A SALUTE TO PARENTHOOD"]. Institute of Technology, [[Nirma University of Science and Technology|Nirma University]], Gujarat won the National Contest while [[Veermata Jijabai Technological Institute|Veermata Jijabai Technological Institute (VJTI)]], Mumbai were the First Runner-up. Both these Institutes got the chance to represent India in the International Contest. [[MIT Robocon Tech Team]] representing [[Maharashtra Institute of Technology]], Pune were the Second Runner-up.
The International ABU Robocon 2014 was held in India.[[Lạc Hồng University]], Vietnam won the International ABU Robocon 2014 held at Balewadi, Pune.
=== Robocon India 2013 === The National ABU Robocon 2013 was held in the Badminton Hall of the Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex, Balewadi, Pune. MIT Tech Team from Maharashtra Institute of Technology won the contest and represented India in the international contest.
The International ABU Robocon 2013 was held in Danang, Vietnam. The Theme for Robocon 2013 declared by [[Vietnam Television|VTV]] was [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qbjooQaMTFA "The Green Planet".] The International ABU Robocon 2013 was won by [[Kanazawa Institute of Technology]], Japan.
=== Robocon India 2012 === The National ABU Robocon 2012 was held in the Boxing Arena of The Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex, Balewadi, Pune. MIT Tech Team from Maharashtra Institute of Technology won the contest and represented India in the international contest.and L.D College of Engineering won the best inovative design award.
The Theme for Robocon 2012 declared by Hong Kong, "Peng On Dai Gat". It was won by University of Electronic Science and Technology of China.
=== Robocon India 2011 === [[File:Robocon India 2011.JPG|thumb|Robocon 2011]]The Theme for Robocon 2011 declared by Thailand was Krathong, Lighting Happiness with Friendship. It was won by Institute of Technology, Nirma University and this institute got a chance to represent India at International Robocon 2011. The winner was Dhurakij Pundit University coming from Thailand.
=== Robocon India 2010. === [[File:Robocon 2010 Winner.JPG|thumb|Robocon 2010 Winner: MIT, Pune]] The Theme for Robocon 2010 declared by Egypt was Robo-Pharaohs Build Pyramids. It was won by [[MIT Robocon Tech Team]] from [[MIT Pune]].<ref name="robocon2010">[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/host-mit-makes-the-cut-wins-robocon-prize/587762/ Host MIT makes the cut, wins Robocon prize]</ref>
=== Robocon India 2009 === Theme of Kago, the traditional Japanese palanquin, carried by human beings replaced by robots. It was won by [[Indian Institute of Technology Madras|IIT Madras]].
=== Robocon India 2008 === [[File:Robocon India 2008.JPG|thumb|Robocon India 2008]]The Theme for Robocon2008 declared by India was Govinda, a traditional Indian Deity who used to play earthly games by capturing Butter/Cheese from heads of Gopis. It was won by [[Nirma Institute of Technology|Institute of Technology, Nirma University]]. Runner-up was [[MIT Robocon Tech Team]] from [[MIT Pune]]. Both team got to represent India in [[ABU Robocon]] as host country gets an opportunity to be represented by two teams.<ref name="robocon2008">[http://punetech.com/nit-mit-beat-vit-and-iit-in-robocon-india/ NIT & MIT beat VIT and IIT in Robocon India]</ref>
=== Robocon India 2007 === The domestic contest was won by IIT Delhi.
=== Robocon India 2006 === The domestic contest was won by Institute of Technology, Nirma University.
=== Robocon India 2003 === The domestic contest was won by Institute of Technology, Nirma University.
=== Robocon India 2002 === The domestic contest was won by Institute of Technology, Nirma University.

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = SelecTV | logo = Selectv.png | type = Subsidiary | foundation = 2005<ref name="wanted">{{cite news | newspaper = [[The Australian]] | title = Wanted: $30m for ethnic pay-TV plan| first = Jane | last = Schulze | page = 19 | date = 18 January 2005 }}</ref> | defunct = January 2011<ref name=selectvclosure>{{cite web|title=Time called on WIN's pay TV company|url=http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/02/04/time-called-on-wins-pay-tv-company/|publisher=The Spy Report (Media Spy)|accessdate=2 March 2011}}</ref> | fate = Under administration | location = Australia | owner = [[Bruce Gordon (businessman)|Bruce Gordon]] | area_served = Australia wide | industry = [[Pay tv]] | products = | revenue = | founder = Jim Blomfield<ref name="wanted"/> | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = [[WIN Corporation]] | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = }}
'''SelecTV''' was an Australian [[satellite]] based [[subscription television]] broadcasting service. As of January 2011, the service is no longer available. Services were carried on the [[Intelsat 8]] satellite.<ref name="Lyngsat">{{cite web | author = Lyngsat |date=17 January 2007|url=http://www.lyngsat.com/packages/selectv.html | title = SelecTV on PAS 8 at 166.0°E | work = Lyngsat | accessdate=20 January 2007}}</ref>
==History== SelecTV was created in [[Melbourne]] in October 2003 by Jim Blomfield,<ref>{{cite news | newspaper = [[Australian Financial Review]] | title = WIN loses three directors| first = Neil | last = Shoebridge | page = 42 | date = 2 August 2010 }}</ref> a former chief executive officer of [[Foxtel]], as i-view Broadcasting Pty, Ltd. It underwent multiple name changes, before finally being renamed as SelecTV Broadcasting Limited in October 2005.<ref name = business1 /> The companies focus was to provide comparatively low-cost premium content to specialist market segments, including Australians whose first [[Languages Other Than English|language was other than English]] and retirees.<ref>{{cite news | newspaper = [[The Australian]] | title = Low-cost ethnic pay-TV looks a lot like Foxtel| first = Jane | last = Schulze| page = 15 | date = 9 March 2006 }}</ref> In August 2006, [[WIN Corporation]] purchased 50.1% of the company for [[Australian dollar|$]]23 million, acquiring overall company control.<ref>{{cite news | title = WIN's $23m bid snares SelecTV| first = By | last = Nabila| page = 3 | newspaper = [[The Age]] | date = 12 August 2006 | accessdate=27 February 2010|url=http://theage.com.au/news/business/wins-23m-bid-snares-selectv/2006/08/11/1154803097530.html}}</ref> By April 2006, the company said it had approximately 2,000 subscribers.<ref name="SelectTV-NZHerald">{{cite web | author = Griffin, Peter | date =24 April 2006 | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/story.cfm?c_id=5&objectid=10378790 | title = Satellite viewing options improve | work = New Zealand Herald Online | accessdate=28 April 2006}}</ref> [[WIN Corporation]] saw opportunity in the companies rapid expansion, and direct competition to the Australian [[subscription television]] giant [[Foxtel]], acquiring the remaining 49.9% from [[Access Providers]] in October 2006.<ref name=wragg>{{cite news |first=Ralph |last=Wragg |title=Access Providers sells SelecTV stake to WIN |publisher=Australian Business News |date=25 October 2006}}</ref> The company expanded its programming to over 40 television channels consisting of English-language channels, as well as various programming packages comprising foreign-language and special interest channels in Greek, Spanish, Italian, German, and Vietnamese.<ref name= business1 >{{cite web |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=24897631 | title=Selectv Broadcasting Ltd.}}</ref> By 2009, due to low subscription to their language packages, SelecTV discontinued all German and Vietnamese programming.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.canberracomms.com.au/selectv_channels.pdf | title=2009 SelecTV channel descriptions|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706102512/http://www.canberracomms.com.au/selectv_channels.pdf|archivedate=8 September 2016}}</ref>
By June 2010, the company had approximately 45,000 subscribers, well short of its target of 80,000.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper = [[The Australian Financial Review]]|title= SelecTV suffers from Freeview blitz|first=Neil|last=Shoebridge|page=41|date=7 June 2010}}</ref> Despite expanding their English language services, SelecTV failed to meet subscriber targets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2010/08/21/selectv-to-withdraw-english-language-service | title=SelecTV to withdraw English language service}}</ref> In August 2010, it was reported that the company would cease broadcasting English programming by 15 November 2010.<ref name="changes">{{cite news | newspaper = [[The Australian]] | title = Bruce Gordon's SelecTV to make changes| first = James | last = Chessell | page = | date = 20 August 2010 | accessdate = 20 August 2010 | url = http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/city-beat/bruce-gordons-selectv-to-make-changes/story-fn4xq4cj-1225907617882}}</ref> On 20 August 2010, SelecTV signed an agreement allowing its 22,000 English subscribers to voluntarily change to [[Foxtel]] and [[Austar]]s subscription services without additional charges. On 30 August 2010, SelecTV sold their Italian language programming to [[World Media International]] and in October their Spanish language programming to [[UBI World TV]].<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Australian Financial Review]]|title =SelecTV runs out of patience|first=Neil|last=Shoebridge|page=40|date=30 August 2010|accessdate=31 August 2010|url=http://www.afr.com/p/business/marketing_media/selectv_runs_out_of_patience_0n3FjKx1cDK7hJsRbPSpdK}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | newspaper = [[Australian Financial Review]] | title = WIN offloads Spanish channels| first = Neil | last = Shoebridge | page = 39 | date = 18 October 2010 }}</ref>
In its final days, SelecTV provided subscription packages for Greek programming.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2010/08/selectv-ceases-english-language-pay-tv.html | title=SelecTV ceases English-language Pay TV}}</ref> On 4 February 2011 SelecTV went into voluntary administration.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2011/02/selecttv-in-voluntary-administration.html | title=SelecTV in voluntary administration}}</ref> On 7 February 2011 a creditors meeting was held where the company revealed that it was in debt of $26 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2011/02/selectv-in-26m-debt.html | title=SelecTV in $25m debt}}</ref> The channel is no longer available in Australia.
==Former channels== *[[Animal Planet (Australia and New Zealand)|Animal Planet]] *[[BBC World News]] *[[Bloomberg Television]] *[[Canal Sur]] *[[Cartoon Network (Australia)|Cartoon Network]] *[[CNN International|CNN]] *[[Deutsche Welle]] (DW-TV, German) *[[Discovery Home & Health]] *[[Science Channel|Discovery Science]] *[[Discovery Turbo (Asia)|Discovery Turbo]] *[[Disney Channel (Australia)|Disney Channel]]<ref name="disney">{{cite news | title = WIN's on to a winner as SelecTV ups service | first = Neil | last =Shoebridge | page = 16 | newspaper = [[The Australian Financial Review]] | location = | date = 15 September 2008 | accessdate = 26 February 2010 | url =http://afr.com/p/business/media_marketing/item_Kg8s7HsBJkxV8WVoNsZibJ?hl}}</ref> *[[E!]] *[[Euronews]] (in Italian, German, Spanish and English)<ref>{{cite journal| journal = Media And Marketing Europe | title = World Digest – Asia-Pacific.| first = | last = | page = 10 | date = 31 October 2006 | accessdate = | url = }}</ref> *[[Eurosport]] Asia Pacific *[[Fashion TV]] *[[Latele Novela Network]] *[[Leonardo World]]<ref>{{cite journal| journal = Video Age International | title = Leonardo World heads to Oz| first = | last = |page = 6 | volume = 26 |issn = 0278-5013| issue = 2 | date = 1 March 2006 | accessdate = 17 October 2010 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Leonardo+World+heads+to+Oz.-a0147057319}}</ref> *[[Movie Network Channels]] (Movie One, Movie Two, Movie Extra, Movie Greats) *[[MTV Australia|MTV]] *[[MTV Classic Australia|MTV Classic]] *[[National Geographic Adventure]] *[[National Geographic Channel (Australia)|National Geographic Channel]] *[[OutTV (Canada)|OutTV]] *[[Ovation (Australian TV channel)|Ovation Channel]]<ref>{{cite journal | journal = B & T Weekly | title = Cultured Australia welcomes advertising as artform| first = Rachel | last = Truman | page = 20 | volume =56 |issue= 2587 | date = 27 October 2006 | accessdate = 17 October 2010 | url = http://www.bandt.com.au/news/advertising-as-art-form}}</ref> *[[Playhouse Disney (Australia and New Zealand)|Playhouse Disney]]<ref name="disney"/> *[[Rai Italia]] *[[Real Madrid TV]] *[[Saigon Broadcasting Television Network|SBTN]] (Vietnamese) *[[Sky Racing]] *[[Televisión Española]] (TVE) *[[Travel and Living Channel]] *[[Turner Classic Movies (Asia)|Turner Classic Movies]] *[[TV Chile]] *[[VTV Uruguay]] *[[Weatherzone]] *[[Wine TV]] (in English and German)

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Shilparatna''' is a classical text on traditional [[South India]]n representational-performing arts. It is particularly influential in painting and theatrical performance. It was authored by Srikumara in 16th century AD. In this the word ''Shilpa'' (sculptural) ''Ratna'' (Gems) is used as a broad term embodying artistic forms that either uses the body as a medium of expression (like [[Dance]], [[Drama]] or Dance-Drama) or that which represents the body as an expression (like Sculptures and [[mural]] arts). It ranks only after the [[Natya Shastra]] and the [[Abhinaya Darpana]] as a text of fundamentals on the performing arts.
It lays down the tenets of painting such as the proper set of colours and the right combinations which leads to stylized balance and rhythm. It is adhered to as principles in South Indian paintings known as Dravidian mural art or [[Dravidian mural painting]]. The text describes yellow, white, red and terreVerte as the pure colours. These colours could be used as single colours or in combinations to make another [[Color|chroma]].
The shilparatna also lays down principles for stage performance, like the optimal space for a performance. The ''[[NatyaGriha]]'' (classical Dance spaces and theatres), ''Natya'' (Postural dance) and ''Griha'' (house) in [[kerala]] is made according to these principles and those laid down by the Natya Shastra. It describes the elaborate codified language of ''[[mudra]]s'' (stylized gestures and symbolic signs by the hands and body posture used in [[Bharatanatyam]] and [[Kathakali]]) as ''angikabhinaya'' meaning body-expressions.
[[Category:Indian painting]] [[Category:Performing arts in India]] [[Category:Arts of Kerala]]

It stars [[Eva Novak]], [[Gertrude Claire]], and George Verrell, and was released in February, 1921. ==Cast list== * [[Eva Novak]] as Louise * [[Gertrude Claire]] as Mrs. Kerran * George Verrell as Amos Kerran * [[Clarissa Selwynne]] as Aunt * William Buckley as Arthur * Ethel Ritchie as Maybelle * [[Lee Shumway]] as George * [[Carl Stockdale]] as Squire * Lucy Donohue as Squire's wife ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0012708}} * {{Tcmdb title|499667}} * {{AFI film|12254}} [[Category:Satire]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Films directed by Leo McCarey]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American silent feature films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] {{US-film-stub}}

[[Austin Spurs]]
[[San Antonio FC]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.spurs.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Spurs Sports & Entertainment L.L.C. (SS&E)''' is an American sports & entertainment organization, based in [[San Antonio|San Antonio, Texas]]. The company owns and operates several sporting franchises including the 5-time [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) champions [[San Antonio Spurs]], the [[American Hockey League]] (AHL)'s [[San Antonio Rampage]], [[NBA G League]]'s [[Austin Spurs]], and the [[United Soccer League]] (USL) club [[San Antonio FC]]. SS&E also operates the Bexar County-owned multi-purpose facility, the [[AT&T Center]]. A 2013 ''[[Forbes]]'' article called the San Antonio Spurs "North America's best run professional sports franchise," {{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/prishe/2013/03/16/san-antonio-spurs-north-americas-best-run-professional-sports-franchise/|title=San Antonio Spurs: North America's Best Run Professional Sports Franchise|first=Patrick|last=Rishe|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} and [[ESPN]] named the Spurs as the best sports franchise in all major sports in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/sportsnation/teamrankings|title=Ultimate Team Rankings - All Sports - SportsNation - ESPN|website=ESPN.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} It was the third time the Spurs received the ESPN honor, and the franchise has ranked in the Top 10 every year since the survey was introduced in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/spurs/news/140919_spurs_named_best_sports_franchise_2014|title=San Antonio Spurs Named Best Sports Franchise in ESPN The Magazine's Ultimate Standings Survey for 2014 - San Antonio Spurs|website=Nba.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} ==Properties== ===San Antonio Spurs=== The '''San Antonio Spurs''' are an American professional [[basketball]] team based in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]]. They are part of the [[Southwest Division (NBA)|Southwest Division]] of the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). They were NBA champions in 1999, 2003, 2005, 2007, and 2014. The Spurs are one of four former [[American Basketball Association]] teams to remain intact in the NBA after the 1976 [[ABA–NBA merger]] and the only former ABA team to have won an [[NBA Finals|NBA championship]]. The Spurs' five NBA championships are the fourth most in history behind only the [[Boston Celtics]] (17), [[Los Angeles Lakers]] (16), and [[Chicago Bulls]] (6). The Spurs currently rank first among active franchises for the highest winning percentage in NBA history. In their 38 NBA seasons since 1976–1977, the Spurs have won 20 division titles. They have made the playoffs in 24 of the last 25 seasons (since 1989–1990) and have missed the playoffs four times since entering the NBA; they have not missed the playoffs in the 18 seasons since [[Tim Duncan]] was drafted by the Spurs in 1997. With their 50th win in the 2014–2015 season, the Spurs extended their record for most consecutive 50+ win seasons to 16 (the 1998/1999 season was shortened to 50 games because of a lockout and based on their win percentage of .740, would have easily surpassed 50 wins in an 82-game season, and thus extend the record by 2 more seasons). Thus, since the 1997/1998 season, the Spurs have had 21 consecutive seasons with a winning percentage of .610 or greater during the regular season which is also an NBA record. ====AT&T Center==== The [[AT&T Center]] is a multi-purpose indoor arena on the east side of [[San Antonio, Texas]]. It seats 18,581 for basketball, 16,000 for ice hockey, and up to 19,000 for concerts or religious gatherings, and contains 2,018 club seats, 60 luxury suites and 32 bathrooms. The arena was completed in 2002, as the SBC Center.{{cite web |url=http://www.attcenter.com/about/about-att-center |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224120708/http://www.attcenter.com/about/about-att-center |archivedate=2013-12-24 |df= }} While [[Bexar County]] owns the arena, SS&E is partnered with the county to manage the day-to-day operations of the AT&T Center. The AT&T Center is undergoing a renovation of more than $100 million, with improvements that include expanded entrances, renovated concourses, new concessions and bar areas, a larger Fan Shop and a new HD video scoreboard. Renovations are scheduled to be completed before the 2015-16 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.newattcenter.com|title=The All-New AT&T Center|website=Newattcenter.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} ===San Antonio Rampage=== The '''[[San Antonio Rampage]]''' are an [[ice hockey]] team in the [[American Hockey League]]. They are the top affiliate of the [[Colorado Avalanche]] of the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]. The Rampage has played in the [[AT&T Center]] in San Antonio, the same arena as the Spurs, since the 2002-03 season. While the Spurs are SS&E's flagship franchise, attendance continues to climb for the Rampage.{{cite web|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local_news/article/Spurs-pass-on-business-success-3797440.php|title=Spurs pass on business success|date=18 August 2012|website=Mysanantonio.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} The team set franchise records for wins and points in the 2014-15 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.sarampage.com/team/news/index.html?article_id=3052|title=Team - San Antonio Rampage Hockey|website=Sarampage.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} ===San Antonio FC === '''[[San Antonio FC]]''' are an American professional [[association football|soccer]] team based in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]]. Founded in 2016, the team debuted in the [[United Soccer League]] [[2016 USL season|that same year]]. It was announced as the league's thirty-first franchise on January 7, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=32800&ATCLID=210620025|title=31st USL Franchise Awarded to San Antonio|publisher=United Soccer League (USL)|date=January 7, 2016|accessdate=January 7, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112044714/http://www.uslsoccer.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=32800&ATCLID=210620025|archivedate=January 12, 2016|df=}} SS&E also operate [[Toyota Field]]. ===Austin Spurs=== The '''[[Austin Spurs]]''' are an American basketball team of the [[NBA G League]] based in [[Austin, Texas]]. The team plays their home games at [[Cedar Park Center]]. They have made the postseason 7 out of their 12 seasons in the NBA Development League/G League, winning the D League/G League Championship in twice in the 2012 {{cite web|url=http://blog.mysanantonio.com/spursnation/2012/04/29/toros-claim-d-league-championship/|title=Spurs|website=San Antonio Express-News|accessdate=29 July 2018}} and 2018 {{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/spurs/austin-spurs-win-2018-nba-g-league-championship|title=Austin Spurs Win 2018 NBA G League Championship - San Antonio Spurs|website=Nba.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} seasons. The team is currently coached by Ken McDonald. Former Austin Spurs in the NBA include [[Danny Green (basketball)|Danny Green]], [[Cory Joseph]], [[Gerald Green]] and [[Alonzo Gee]]. ==Partners== Spurs Sports & Entertainment listed the following partners as of October 2014:{{Cite web |url=http://spursdotcom.com/pdf/2%20-%20MG%20SS%26E.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-11-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150416132119/http://spursdotcom.com/pdf/2%20-%20MG%20SS%26E.pdf# |archive-date=2015-04-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }} {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[ARAMARK]] Sports & Entertainment Group *Raymond Joseph Barshick *Cassandra Carr *[[Clear Channel]] Communications Inc. *George C. "Tim" Hixon *[[Peter Holt]] - Chairman *IBC Capital Corporation *Sylvan Stephen Lang *James R. Leininger *R&B Partnership (Russell and Bruce Hill) *[[David Robinson (basketball)|David Robinson]] *[[AT&T]] Media Holdings, Inc. *Markey Family Partnership *Sierra Sports & Entertainment Family Limited Partnership *[[SWBC]] *Sunrise Sports & Entertainment *[[Valero Energy Corporation]] *Zachry Hospitality Corporation *Estate of Jeanne Lang Mathews *[[LAZ parking]] {{Div col end}} The nonprofit partner of SS&E is Silver & Black Give Back,{{Cite web |url=http://www.sbgb.org/about-us/who-we-are/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-04-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414013147/http://www.sbgb.org/about-us/who-we-are/# |archive-date=2015-04-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }} a [[501(c)(3)]] that sponsors two key initiatives, Team Up Challenge,{{cite web|url=http://www.teamupchallenge.com/|title=Silver and Black Give Back|website=Teamupchallenge.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} a service-based learning program, and youth sports programs such as the Spurs Youth League.{{Cite web |url=http://www.sbgb.org/programs/youth-sports/about/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-04-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414013146/http://www.sbgb.org/programs/youth-sports/about/# |archive-date=2015-04-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Former properties== ===San Antonio Stars=== The '''[[San Antonio Stars]]''' played in the [[Western Conference (WNBA)|Western Conference]] in the [[Women's National Basketball Association]] (WNBA). The team was founded in [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]] as the [[Utah Starzz]] before the league's inaugural [[1997 WNBA season|1997 season]] began; the team moved to San Antonio before the [[2003 WNBA season|2003 season]]. The Stars qualified for the [[WNBA Playoffs]] in seven of their twelve years in San Antonio. The franchise while in San Antonio was home to many high-quality players such as all-star point guard [[Becky Hammon]], solid power forward [[Sophia Young]], two [[List of first overall WNBA draft picks|#1 overall draft picks]] in [[Ann Wauters]] and [[Kelsey Plum]], and seven-foot-two-inch center [[Margo Dydek]]. In [[2008 WNBA season|2008]], the Silver Stars went to the [[WNBA Finals]]. On August 5, 2014, Hammon was hired by the Spurs as an assistant coach, becoming the second female assistant coach in NBA history but the first full-time assistant coach.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/wnba/story/_/id/11313239/wnba-san-antonio-stars-future-spurs-assistant-becky-hammon-was-born-coach|title=Fagan: Becky Hammon was born to coach|website=Espn.go.com|accessdate=29 July 2018}} This also made her the first full-time female assistant coach in any of the [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|four major professional sports]] in North America. In October 2017, multiple media reports indicated that SS&E was nearing completion of the sale of the Stars to a group that would move the team to [[Las Vegas]] for the 2018 season and beyond.{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/wnba/story/_/id/21005369/wnba-san-antonio-stars-deal-las-vegas-relocation |title=WNBA's San Antonio Stars have deal for Las Vegas relocation |website=Espn.com|date=October 12, 2017 |accessdate=October 13, 2017}} The team was sold to [[MGM Resorts International]] and moved to Las Vegas prior to the [[2018 WNBA season]], and is now known as the [[Las Vegas Aces]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Spurs Sports & Entertainment}} {{San Antonio Spurs}} {{San Antonio Rampage}} {{NBAOwners}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Spurs Sports and Entertainment}} [[Category:Spurs Sports & Entertainment]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in San Antonio]] [[Category:San Antonio Spurs]] [[Category:Sports management companies]] [[Category:Sports in San Antonio]] [[Category:Companies established in 1967]] [[Category:1967 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:San Antonio Rampage]] [[Category:San Antonio Stars]] [[Category:San Antonio FC]]

{{Infobox film |name = The 9/11 Commission Report |image = |caption = |director = Leigh Scott |producer = {{ubl|[[David Michael Latt]]|Sherri Strain }} |writer = Leigh Scott |starring =Rhett Giles |music = Eliza Swenson |cinematography = Steven Parker |editing = Kristen Quintrall
Leigh Scott |distributor = The Asylum |released = {{Film date|2006}} |runtime = 86 minutes |language = English |country = United States |budget = $1,000,000 }} '''The 9/11 Commission Report''' is a 2006 drama film produced by the Asylum. It was written and directed by Leigh Scott and released June 2006.[http://www.theasylum.cc/ The 9/11 Commission Report] The Asylum. ==Plot== The movie is a dramatization of the findings laid out in [[The 9/11 Commission Report]], a document that sought to analyze the circumstances surrounding coordinated terrorist attacks against American civilians on Sept 11 2001. {{cite web|url=https://letterboxd.com/film/the-9-11-commission-report/|title=The 9/11 Commission Report (2006)|publisher=}} ==Cast== * Rhett Giles as Mike * Jeff Denton as Jack * Eliza Swenson as Rosalind * Sarah Lieving as Valerie * Marat Glazer as Yousef ==Reception== Film Monthly stated that the film "has quality, and in spades. “The 9/11 Commission Report” is a surprisingly clever piece of historical dramatization" {{cite web|url=http://www.filmmonthly.com/steve_anderson/the_911_commission_report.html|title=Film Monthly.com – Steve Anderson – The 9/11 Commission Report|website=www.filmmonthly.com}} ==References== ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0840272}} {{DEFAULTSORT:9/11 Commission Report}} [[Category:2006 films]] [[Category:2000s independent films]] [[Category:2006 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American disaster films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films based on the September 11 attacks]] [[Category:Films directed by Leigh Scott]] [[Category:The Asylum films]]

{{mapbox|type=shape-inverse|zoom=17}} [[Image:Fox Studios Australia 1.JPG|thumb|250px|Fox Studios Australia]] '''The Entertainment Quarter''' is an entertainment precinct in the [[Eastern Suburbs (Sydney)|Eastern Suburbs]] of [[Sydney, Australia]]. The Entertainment Quarter sits beside [[Fox Studios Australia]] in the [[suburb]] of [[Moore Park, New South Wales|Moore Park]], located 3 kilometres south-east of the [[Sydney central business district]] and is part of [[Local government in Australia|local government area]] of the [[City of Sydney]].
==Facilities== The precinct features many specialty shops, bars, cafes, restaurants, two cinemas (both owned by [[Hoyts]]), live entertainment venues including a comedy store and function centre, children's playground, parklands and entertainment sporting facilities such as [[ten pin bowling]] and an [[ice rink]] during winter.
The Showring hosts a Farmer's Market on Wednesdays and Saturdays and a Merchandise Market on Saturdays and Sundays. Retailers include music retailer [[Sanity (music store)|Sanity]], and fashion stores [[Esprit Holdings|Esprit]] and Bay Swiss.
==History== The Entertainment Quarter and Fox Studios Australia, were originally the site of [[Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales]] Sydney Showground which hosted the annual [[Sydney Royal Easter Show]]. The Sydney Showground moved to [[Homebush Bay, New South Wales|Homebush Bay]] in preparation for the [[2000 Summer Olympics]]. Some of the venues built for the [[Olympic Games]] are now used for the annual show.
Fox Studios Australia and the entertainment precinct opened at Moore Park in 1998. A theme park at this location was closed and some of the facilities have found new uses in 'The Entertainment Quarter'.
<gallery> Image:Entertainment Quarter Bent Street.JPG| Bent Street Image:Entertainment Quarter Cinema.JPG|[[Hoyts]] Cinemas Image:Entertainment Quarter Showground 3.JPG|Old Showring Image:Entertainment Quarter Showring Markets.JPG|Showring markets Image:Entertainment Quarter Hordern Pavilion.JPG|[[Hordern Pavilion]] Image:Entertainment Quarter Royal Hall of Industries.JPG|Royal Hall of Industries Image:Royal hall of industry0004.jpg|Royal Hall of Industries Image:Entertainment Quarter Commemorative Pavilion.JPG|Commemorative Pavilion Image:Entertainment Quarter Showground 1.JPG|Old Showground Image:Entertainment Quarter Showground 2.JPG|Old Showground </gallery>
==External links== * [http://www.entertainmentquarter.com.au The Entertainment Quarter] * [http://www.foxstudiosaustralia.com Fox Studios Australia]
{{Sydney landmarks}} {{News Corporation}}

revision.comment: /* Revised version */ quotation per citation + cn
revision.text:
{{for|the book about Lowry Park Zoo|Zoo Story: Life in the Garden of Captives}} {{italic title}} [[Image:Zoo-story-kufa-betz 19.JPG|thumb|right|333px|''The Zoo Story''; photograph from a Luxembourgish production]] '''''The Zoo Story''''' is a one-act play by American [[playwright]] [[Edward Albee]]. His first play, it was written in 1958 and completed in just three weeks.<ref>[http://web.csustan.edu/english/reuben/pal/chap8/albee.html Reuben, Paul P. "Chapter 8: Edward Albee."] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120716185246/http://web.csustan.edu/english/reuben/pal/chap8/albee.html |date=2012-07-16 }}, ''Perspectives in American Literature- A Research and Reference Guide'', Retrieved June 28, 2007</ref> The play explores themes of isolation, loneliness, miscommunication as anathematization, social disparity and dehumanization in a materialistic world. Today, professional theatre companies can produce "The Zoo Story" either as a part of "Edward Albee's at Home at the Zoo" (originally titled "Peter and Jerry"), or as a standalone play. Its prequel, "Homelife" written in 2004, however, can only be produced as a part of "Edward Albee's at Home at the Zoo".
==Productions== Rejected by [[New York City|New York]] producers, the play premiered in [[West Berlin]] at the [[Schiller Theater]] ''Werkstatt'' on 28 September 1959 in a double bill with the German premiere of [[Samuel Beckett]]'s ''[[Krapp's Last Tape]]''.<ref>Halliwell, Martin. "Drama and Performance", ''American Culture in the 1950s'', Edinburgh University Press, 2007, {{ISBN|0748618856}}, p. 107</ref><ref>Harris, Andrew Bennett. "Chapter 6", ''Broadway Theatre'', Psychology Press, 1994, {{ISBN|041510520X}}, p. 82</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=264tAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YZ8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=7261%2C2099084 "Edward Albee Play at Place de Arts"] ''The Montreal Gazette'', October 10, 1964</ref>
The play premiered in the United States [[Off-Broadway]] in a production by Theatre 1960 at the [[Provincetown Playhouse]] on January 14, 1960 and closed on May 21, 1961. The play was paired with ''Krapp's Last Tape''. Directed by Milton Katselas, the cast was [[William Daniels]] (Peter) and [[George Maharis]] (Jerry).<ref name=lortel/><ref name= "plays">{{cite news |last= |first= |url= http://www.provincetownplayhouse.com/plays1960s.html |title=Plays Produced in the Provincetown Playhouse in 1960s Chronological |work=[[Provincetown Playhouse]] |date= |accessdate=2012-09-02}}</ref> who was replaced by [[Peter Mark Richman]] (then known as Mark Richman) after a week. Daniels and Richman performed to rave reviews for more than nine months. The play won the 1960 [[Obie Award]] for Distinguished Play and Distinguished Performance, William Daniels.<ref name=lortel>[http://www.lortel.org/lla_archive/index.cfm?search_by=show&id=4466 ''Krapp's Last Tape/ The Zoo Story''] lortel.org, accessed November 20, 2015</ref> (Michael Karlan replaced Mark Richman for 6 weeks when Richman left the show to shoot a film.)
== Plot summary == This one-act play concerns two characters, Peter and Jerry, who meet on a park bench in [[New York City]]'s [[Central Park]]. Peter is a wealthy publishing executive with a wife, two daughters, two cats, and two parakeets. Jerry is an isolated and disheartened man, desperate to have a meaningful conversation with another human being. He intrudes on Peter’s peaceful state by interrogating him and forcing him to listen to stories about his life and the reason behind his visit to the [[Central Park Zoo|zoo]]. The action is linear, unfolding in front of the audience in “real time”. The elements of ironic humor and unrelenting dramatic suspense are brought to a climax when Jerry brings his victim down to his own savage level.
Eventually, Peter has had enough of his strange companion and tries to leave. Jerry begins pushing Peter off the bench and challenges him to fight for his territory. Unexpectedly, Jerry pulls a knife on Peter, and then drops it as initiative for Peter to grab. When Peter holds the knife defensively, Jerry charges him and impales himself on the knife. Bleeding on the park bench, Jerry finishes his ''zoo story'' by bringing it into the immediate present: "Could I have planned all this. No... no, I couldn't have. But I think I did." Horrified, Peter runs away from Jerry, whose dying words, "Oh...my...God", are a combination of scornful mimicry and supplication.
== Revised version== Albee wrote a prequel to ''The Zoo Story'', titled ''Homelife''. ''Homelife'' is written as the first act, with ''The Zoo Story'' as the second act, in a new play called ''[[Edward Albee's At Home at the Zoo]]'' (initially titled ''Peter & Jerry''). ''Homelife'' was first read publicly at the [[Last Frontier Theatre Conference]].
Christopher Wallenberg wrote of ''The Zoo Story'': "Over the years, he'd [Albee] always had a nagging feeling that something was missing from the piece’s unsettling encounter between two very different men on a Central Park bench ..." Albee said: "''The Zoo Story'' is a good play. It's a play that I'm very happy I wrote. But it's a play with one and a half characters. Jerry is a fully developed, three-dimensional character. But Peter is a backboard. He’s not fully developed. Peter had to be more fleshed out."<ref name=boston>{{cite news|last=Wallenberg|first=Christopher|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2011/05/08/edward_albee_finally_finishes_zoo_story|title=For decades, playwright was captivated by ''Zoo''|work=The Boston Globe|date=May 8, 2011}}</ref>
{{citation needed span|date=September 2018|text=In addition to discussions about his adding an act and a character nearly 50 years after writing the original play, the theater community was taken aback by Albee's announcement that he would no longer permit ''The Zoo Story'' to be produced by professional theater companies. He would only allow the two-act play. The move has raised controversy within the theater community. Only non-professional and college theaters may produce ''The Zoo Story'' in its original version. Albee defended the change and the addition of a female character, Peter's wife. Albee noted the play was his to do with as he wanted.}}
===Production history=== The two-act play ''Peter and Jerry'' had its world premiere at the Hartford Stage in 2004, with Pam MacKinnon directing and [[Frank Wood (actor)|Frank Wood]] as Peter.<ref>Bovard, Karen. [https://muse.jhu.edu/journals/theatre_journal/v056/56.4bovard.html "'Peter and Jerry'. Act I: Homelife. Act II: The Zoo Story (review)"] Theatre Journal 56.4, 991-993 (muse.jhu.edu), December 2004</ref>
The play was produced Off-Broadway at the [[Second Stage Theatre]] in 2007, and starred [[Bill Pullman]], Dallas Roberts and [[Johanna Day]]. It was titled ''Peter and Jerry''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lortel.org/Archives/Production/4597|title=''Peter and Jerry''|website=Lortel Archives}}</ref>
The play, titled ''Edward Albee's At Home at the Zoo'' played at [[American Conservatory Theatre]] in San Francisco in June 2009, with [[Anthony Fusco]] as Peter, René Augesen as his wife Ann, and Manoel Felciano as Jerry.<ref>[http://www.act-sf.org/content/dam/act/education_department/words_on_plays/Edward%20Albee's%20At%20Home%20at%20the%20Zoo%20Words%20on%20Plays%20(2009).pdf "''At Home at the Zoo'' at ACT"] act-sf.org, accessed November 21, 2015</ref>
As of December 2009 it played in its Seattle premiere at Theater Schmeater.
''At Home at the Zoo'' had its premiere Pittsburgh production and was the inaugural show for the Ghostlight Theatre Troupe in Gibsonia, PA in July 2010. It starred Rich Kenzie as Peter, Mary Romeo as Ann and Ned Johnstone as Jerry and was directed by Gabe Herlinger.<ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2010/07/18/2Do-Calendar-for-7-18-10/stories/201007180255 ”2Do Calendar for 7/18/10"] ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette'', July 18, 2010</ref>
''At Home at the Zoo'' opened on February 23, 2018 at New York's The Signature Theater, starring Katie Finneran, Robert Sean Leonard and Paul Sparks.<ref>[http://www.playbill.com/article/edward-albees-at-home-at-the-zoo-begins-off-broadway “Edward Albee’s At Home at the Zoo Begins Off-Broadway”] ''Playbill'', January 30, 2018</ref>
== In popular culture == ''The Zoo Story'' is referenced in the film ''[[Grumpy Old Men (film)|Grumpy Old Men]]''.
''The Zoo Story'' is a central element in the novel "Qiṣṣat hadīqat al-ḥayawān" (The zoo story), by Moroccan playwright and novelist Yūsuf Fāḍil, published Dār al-Fanak, Casablanca, 2008, which deals with the milieu of actors and playwrights in 1970s Morocco and Moroccans in Paris. The two main characters of the novel, Al-Sīmū and Rašīd, want to perform a Moroccan version of the play, but their copy of Albee's work is missing essential pages.
The Zoo Story is referenced in [[Jay McInerney]]'s ''[[Story of My Life (novel)|Story of My Life]]''.
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Albee}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Zoo Story}} [[Category:Plays by Edward Albee|Zoo Story, The]] [[Category:1958 plays|Zoo Story, The]] [[Category:Debut plays]] [[Category:One-act plays]] [[Category:Plays set in New York City]] [[Category:Works originally published in Evergreen Review]] [[Category:Two-handers]]

revision.text:
'''Tom E. Finglass''' (1880? – 1957) was an Irish [[blackface]] tenor who had a successful career in British [[music hall]]. He was sometimes billed as ''The Ideal Coon''. He played the legendary blackface performer [[Eugene Stratton]] (1861–1918) in the 1940 film ''[[You Will Remember]]'' which tells the story of song writer [[Leslie Stuart]]'s (1863–1928) life.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=KtZ22A3HL5AC&pg=PA203&dq=Lily+of+Laguna+stuart&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Qy1jUeXgCaS40QWym4CADw&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Lily%20of%20Laguna%20stuart&f=falseYou Will Remember] Your Colossal Main Feature Plus Full Sup Volume 7 of Hollywood classics , John Reid, 2005. {{ISBN|1411629094}}</ref><ref>[http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2b6bb7a249 You Will Remember] British Film Institute. Accessed 2013</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=p6UV_Y76mUgC&pg=PA225&lpg=PA225&dq=Tom+Finglass&source=bl&ots=x4zzyDOIOf&sig=VlQL7WvGEqUS6QlEtp_ZQSObvGE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=vT1pUe_wNaW80QXFrYGwAg&ved=0CFUQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Tom%20Finglass&f=false You Will Remember] John Reid, Hollywood Movie Musicals, 2006, page 225. {{ISBN|1411697626}}</ref>
Finglass was born in Dublin. In 1930 he teamed up with songwriter [[Fred Godfrey]] to create a variety act featuring Godfrey’s hit songs. Finglass would sing while Godfrey played the piano. The act was extremely successful and topped the bill at venues in the 1930s<ref name="Norris"/>
Finglass retired from regular performing in the late 1930s and subsequently made his living in London as a hairdresser. He appeared in the 1943 film ''[[Variety Jubilee]]'', playing Eugene Stratton. The film depicts life in a London music hall from 1892 to the 1940s.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A2B4akeeB4A Variety Jubilee] at the IMDB. Accessed April 2013</ref> He also came out of retirement briefly in 1950 to portray Stratton once more in a [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] tribute to that singer.<ref name="Norris">[http://www.fredgodfreysongs.ca/Artists/finglass_tom.htm Tom E. Finglass (1880?–1957)] at Bless ’Em All: The Songs of Fred Godfrey , Barry Norris. Accessed 2013 </ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
* S. Theodore Felstead, Stars Who Made the Halls: A Hundred Years of English Humour, Harmony and Hilarity (London: T. Werner Laurie, 1946), p. 58. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A2B4akeeB4A Lily of Laguna] sung in the 1934 film ''[[Those Were the Days (1934 film)|Those were the days]]''. The film credits the singer as [[G H Elliott]], however the artist bears no resemblance to Elliott but does resemble Finglass.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Finglass, Tom E.}} [[Category:People from Dublin (city)]] [[Category:1880s births]] [[Category:1957 deaths]] [[Category:Music hall performers]]
{{Ireland-music-bio-stub}}

{{orphan|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox video game | title = Ve stínu havrana | image = Ve stínu havrana cover.jpg | caption = | developer = Rainbow Rhino
[[Cinemax (video game developer)|Cinemax]]{{cite web|title=Ve stínu havrana|url=https://www.databaze-her.cz/hry/ve-stinu-havrana/|website=www.databaze-her.cz|accessdate=30 March 2018|language=cs}} | publisher = Cinemax | director = | producer = | designer = | programmer = | artist = | writer = | composer = | series = | engine = | platforms = DOS, Windows | released = 1999 | genre = [[Adventure game]]| modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |alt = }}'''''Ve stínu havrana''''' (English: '''''In the Raven Shadow''''') is a 1999 Czech-Slovak adventure game developed by Rainbow Rhino and published by CINEMAX.{{cite web|url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/ve-stnu-havrana|title=Ve stínu havrana for Windows (1999) - MobyGames|website=MobyGames}} ==Production== The game was created by Jiří Lábus.{{Cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/ve-stinu-havrana-steam-0b1-/Novinky.aspx?c=A170712_092951_bw-novinky_srp|title=Legendární česká adventura Ve Stínu Havrana je nyní na Steamu|date=2017-07-12|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-05-24}} The first edition of the game became sold out in less than a year.{{Cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/cinemax-chysta-radu-zajimavych-titulu-dht-/Novinky.aspx?c=A000620_cinemaxvyvoj000622_bw|title=Cinemax chystá řadu zajímavých titulů|date=2000-06-22|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-05-24}} The title saw three editions, and became a magazine attachment 8 times; it was played by 250,000 players.{{Cite web|url=http://gamesweb.sk/5406/archiv-noviniek/ve-stinu-havrana-2.html|title=Ve Stínu Havrana 2, Archív noviniek, GamesWeb.sk|last=balky|website=gamesweb.sk|language=en|access-date=2018-05-24}} In 2008, work was being done on a second game, however it was never released.{{cite web|url=http://www.abcgames.cz/?p=hry_zobraz&id=11324|title=Ve stínu havrana 2|website=ABCgames.cz}} The game is currently available on Steam{{cite web|url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/656570/In_the_Raven_Shadow__Ve_stnu_havrana/|title=In the Raven Shadow – Ve stínu havrana on Steam|website=store.steampowered.com}}, and was uploaded on July 12, 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/top-5-cervenec-2017-0jh-/Magazin.aspx?c=A170630_134949_bw-magazin_oz|title=Pět nejočekávanějších červencových her|date=2017-07-03|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-05-24}} ==Plot and gameplay== The player takes control of the good-natured monk Severin, who one day "escapes" from the monastery and decides to seek his way of life. ==Critical reception== Gamershell found enjoyment from the game despite its bare sound and visuals, and silly script.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamershell.com/pc/in_the_raven_shadow/review.html|title=In The Raven Shadow Review|website=www.gamershell.com}} Absolute Games offered a mixed assessment of the game.{{cite web|url=http://www.ag.ru/games/in-the-raven-shadow/review|title=Тень ворона (In the Raven Shadow) - рецензия и обзор на игру на AG.ru|website=www.ag.ru}} Just Adventure decided that players willing to overlook the game's technical limitations would find enjoyment from its witty sense of humour.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040415040431/http://www.justadventure.com/reviews/ShadowRaven/ShadowRaven.shtm|title=In the Shadow of the Raven Review - Just Adventure +|date=15 April 2004|publisher=}} Bonusweb.cz felt that if the idea of the game bored players, they could wait another week for Czech adventure game [[Hot Summer 2]] to be released.{{cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/ve-stinu-havrana-02y-/Recenze.aspx?c=A000404_vestinuhavrana_bw|title=Ve stínu Havrana|date=8 June 1999|website=iDNES.cz}} Bonusweb asserted that the game is likely known by every Czech computer player. ==Sequel== [[Cinemax (video game developer)|Cinemax]] announced works on '''Ve stínu havrana 2''' in 2007. It was scheduled for a release in the second quarter of 2008.{{cite web|title=Ve Stínu Havrana 2|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/ve-stinu-havrana-2-0zr-/Novinky.aspx?c=A071016_vestinuhavrana2n071018_bw|website=iDNES.cz|accessdate=30 March 2018|date=18 October 2007}}{{Cite web|url=http://pc.hrej.cz/hry/adventura/2d-adventura/ve-stinu-havrana-2/|title=Ve stínu havrana 2|website=Hrej.cz|access-date=2018-05-24}} It was a collaboration between House of Dragonflies and Cinemax, and contained the work of graphic designers Erik Sille and Boris Sirka.{{Cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/ve-stinu-havrana-2-nove-info-dfi-/Zurnal.aspx?c=A071004_vestinuhavrana2infz071004_bw|title=Ve Stínu Havrana 2 - nové info|date=2007-10-04|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-05-24}} The game's plot would have seen the monk Severin be trapped between medieval Europe, and futuristic world guided by Plato's philosophy of perfect States.{{Cite news|url=https://doupe.zive.cz/clanek/odhaleno-pokracovani-adventury-ve-stinu-havrana|title=Odhaleno pokračování adventury Ve stínu havrana|last=Viktorin|first=Rosťa|work=Doupe.cz|access-date=2018-05-24|language=cs}} The game was inspired by the works of PKDick, W. Gibson, and T. Giliam's film productions.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sector.sk/novinka/36064/havran-sa-vracia.htm|title=Havran sa vracia|last=s.r.o.|first=Sector|website=Sector.sk|access-date=2018-05-24}} It was a 3D point-and-click adventure with a non-linear story, while featuring limited RPG elements.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hrej.cz/novinky/2007/10/03/cinemax-chysta-ve-stinu-havrana-2-14503/|title=Cinemax chystá Ve stínu havrana 2 - Hrej.cz|work=Hrej.cz|access-date=2018-05-24}} The game was reported as being make completely in Czech, including its dubbing.{{Cite web|url=http://www.recenzeher.eu/preview-clanek/ve-stinu-havrana-2/|title=Preview - Ve stínu havrana 2, - Recenzeher.eu|last=admin@recenzeher.eu|first=RecenzeHer.eu -|website=www.recenzeher.eu|language=cs|access-date=2018-05-24}} It promsied to touch on historical themes and insights into philosophy, religion, mathematics, and cybernetics.{{Cite news|url=https://pcworld.cz/hry/pokracovani-ceske-adventury-ve-stinu-havrana-41039|title=Pokračování české adventury Ve Stínu Havrana|last=Prošek|first=Petr|access-date=2018-05-24|language=cs}} Development was eventually cancelled.{{cite web|last1=hodnoceniher.cz|first1=webmaster z|title=Ve Stínu Havrana 2 (HRA ZRUŠENA!) - recenze, hodnocení|url=http://www.hodnoceniher.cz/pc/adventury/ve-stinu-havrana-2.html|website=www.hodnoceniher.cz|accessdate=30 March 2018|language=cs}} Bonusweb felt it was a shame the project never took off, as it seemed like an "interesting psychedelic affair". ==References== {{reflist}} {{video game stub}} [[Category:1999 video games]] [[Category:DOS games]] [[Category:Point-and-click adventure games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Video games developed in Slovakia]] [[Category:Windows games]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name = Web3D Consortium |bgcolor = |fgcolor = |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = {{Start date and age|1997|paren=yes}} |type = [[non-profit organization|NPO]] |status = [[501(c)(3)]] private |purpose = |headquarters = [[Mountain View, California]]
{{Coordinates|37|23|16.7|N|122|04|58.2|W|}} |location = |region_served = |membership = |language = [[American English|English]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Nicholas Polys |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{URL|web3d.org}} |remarks = }} The '''Web3D Consortium''' is an international [[non-profit organization|not-for-profit]], member-funded industry [[consortium]], originally founded in 1997. In the Web3D Consortium members from governmental, nonprofit and research organizations worldwide, working alongside individual professional members, collaborate in a consensus process encouraging development and implementation of open standards for 3D content and services. The Web3D Consortium promotes deployment of X3D standards for the communication of 3D scenes in multiple applications, use cases, platforms, and verticals. Members collaboratively develop the X3D standards and tools making them widely adopted across diverse markets for academia, government, industry, and individuals. The Web3D Consortium offers robust ISO standardized 3D functionality and long-term stability for enterprise solutions and interoperability with other 3D standards. The Consortium defines and develops the X3D royalty-free [[open standard]]s [[file format]] and [[Run-time system|runtime]] architecture to represent and communicate [[3D computer graphics|3D scenes]]. The development of [[Web3D|3D web-based graphics]] has evolved from its beginnings as the Virtual Reality Modeling Language ([[VRML]]) to Extensible 3D ([[X3D]]). Over recent years, advances in real time graphics and networking technology, and most notably the emergence of the Extensible Markup Language [[XML]], have heavily influenced the development of the [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]]-approved, freely available, X3D open standard. X3D embodies best practices in commercial real time graphics within the widely adopted framework of the [[World Wide Web]] family of technologies and standards and has no intellectual property restrictions. It provides a system for the storage, retrieval and playback of real time graphics content embedded in applications, all within an [[open architecture]] to support a wide array of domains and user scenarios. [[Web3D]] applications have been active for some time. Previously known as the [[VRML]] Consortium, this community spearheaded the development of the VRML 1.0 and 2.0 specifications, which provide the basis for the development of associated applications. The organizations involved in this effort felt that the creation of an open consortium focused exclusively on Web3D would provide the structure necessary to stabilize, standardize, and nurture the technology for the entire community. Today, the Web3D Consortium is utilizing its broad-based industry support to develop the X3D specification as a successor to VRML for communicating 3D on the web, between applications and across distributed networks and web services. Related to its educational mission, the Consortium maintains an extensive website of documents and links related to VRML and X3D resources, including plugins and browsers from many long term members and open source developers. ==See also== * [[VRML]], the first ISO-standard format for 3D browsing * [[X3D]], modern descendant of VRML that includes [[XML]] encoding * [[Web3D]] * [[WebGL]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.web3d.org/ Web3D Consortium] * [http://xml.coverpages.org/vrml-X3D.html VRML (Virtual Reality Modeling Language) and X3D] {{vector graphics markup languages}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Web3d Consortium}} [[Category:Computer graphics organizations]] [[Category:Graphics standards]] [[Category:ISO standards]] [[Category:Markup languages]] [[Category:Mountain View, California]] [[Category:Virtual reality organizations]] {{Computer-stub}}
